{"uri": "8161306686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:39:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:39:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:38:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13493501/MLB-bans-Tucupita-Marcano-life-betting-baseball-four-one-year-suspensions.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball\u00b4s rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team\u00b4s major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nFILE - San Diego Padres baseball infielder Tucupita Marcano poses for a photo Feb. 20, 2024, in Peoria, Ariz. Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe. MLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing. (AP Photo/Lindsey Wasson, File)\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB\n\nFILE - Pittsburgh Pirates shortstop Tucupita Marcano takes a throw down to second base during the fifth inning of a baseball game against the Arizona Diamondbacks, July 7, 2023, in Phoenix. San Diego Padres' Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing. (AP Photo/Ross D. {"uri": "2024-06-378540567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:38:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:38:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:22:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_1ea67e29-25b7-5f16-8ed5-3d6a8ada55be.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "FILE - Pittsburgh Pirates shortstop Tucupita Marcano takes a throw down to second base during the fifth inning of a baseball game against the Arizona Diamondbacks, July 7, 2023, in Phoenix. San Diego Padres' Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-378546817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:44:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:44:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:22:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/state_news/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_ac774a7b-cbbb-5cfb-aad4-dac6dc22e88e.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "Major League Baseball has permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB", "source": {"uri": "maryvilleforum.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8161491069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:44:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:44:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:43:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.espn.ph/mlb/story/_/id/40275531/tucupita-marcano-gets-life-mlb-ban-betting-baseball", "title": "Marcano gets lifetime ban for betting on MLB", "body": "Major League Baseball has permanently banned Tucupita Marcano after determining that the infielder placed hundreds of bets on baseball, including wagers on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates when he was with the team last season.\n\nMLB announced Marcano's lifetime ban Tuesday, saying that an investigation showed he violated Rule 21(d)(2) of the league's betting rules and policies.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano, currently a member of the San Diego Padres, was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000.\n\nMLB says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets, according to the league.\n\nRule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jose Rodriguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on -- testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-378682994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:51:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:51:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:29:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://who13.com/news/mlb-bans-san-diego-padres-infielder-for-life-for-sports-betting/", "title": "MLB bans San Diego Padres infielder for life for sports betting", "body": "SAN DIEGO (KSWB/KUSI) -- Major League Baseball has permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for violating the league's gambling policy. Four other players have been placed on one-year suspensions for unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nThe announcement comes one day after the investigation into bets made by the 24-year-old on baseball was made public. According to reports, the alleged sports betting occurred last year while Marcano was on the injured list after sustaining a season-ending ACL injury in July.\n\nOn Tuesday, MLB officials said their investigation found Marcano had placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers between Oct. 16, 2022, and Nov. 1, 2023. All wagers totaled over $150,000.\n\nAt the time, the infielder was with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Marcano was first signed by the Padres as an amateur free agent from Venezuela in 2016, and traded to the Pirates five years later. He returned to the Padres in November on waivers. He has spent much of the season on the injured list.\n\nOf the bets he placed, MLB officials said 25 were wagers on Pirates games while he was injured, but still on the team's roster. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nAccording to the league, a legal sportsbook operator tipped off MLB officials about the activity.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nThe 24-year-old appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nAnother major leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia, and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nNone of the players punished on Tuesday played in games they bet on, according to league officials. All also denied to the MLB that they had inside information relevant to the games they bet on, aligning with the testimony given by the sportsbook operator who tipped off the league.\n\nIn a statement, Padres officials said they \"cannot comment on violations that occurred outside of our organization,\" but added they \"fully support MLB's sports betting policy and the need to adhere to all provisions of Rule 21.\"\n\n\"We will continue to educate all members of our organization regarding their obligations under the policy,\" the statement continued.\n\nUnder Major League Rule 21, betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official, or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a ban.", "source": {"uri": "who13.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "who13.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161541304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:22:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:22:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:21:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.oann.com/newsroom/tucupita-marcano-given-lifetime-ban-from-mlb-4-others-suspended-1-year-for-baseball-betting/", "title": "Tucupita Marcano Given Lifetime Ban From MLB, 4 Others Suspended 1 Year For Baseball Betting", "body": "Major League Baseball (MLB) has permanently banned San Diego Padres player Tucupita Marcano after discovering that he placed hundreds of bets on different MLB games, including Pittsburgh Pirates games when he was still with that team last season.\n\nMLB Commissioner Rob Manfred made the announcement on Tuesday, explaining that the investigation showed that Marcano violated Rule 21(d)(2) of the league's betting rules and policies.\n\nAdditionally, four other players received one year suspensions for betting on other teams as well, which includes Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher Andrew Saalfrank, Padres pitcher Jay Groome, and Philadelphia Phillies infielder Jose Rodriguez.\n\nThe investigation revealed that Marcano was found to have bet on the Pirates while he was still on their injured list (IL).\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano becomes the first active major league player banned under the MLB's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924.\n\nThe investigation also showed that Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between October 16, 2022, and November 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000.\n\nThe MLB also stated that 25 of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's roster. However, Marcano did not play in any of those games due to being on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets, according to the MLB.\n\nAccording to Spotrac, the 24-year-old has made $2.7 million so far during his baseball career. He has a career .217 average and .589 OPS in 149 games.\n\nRule 21, which is posted in every team's clubhouse, states that betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official, or team employee that has \"no duty to perform,\" results in a one-year suspension. Additionally, betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nThe league stated that they were tipped off about the illegal betting by an unidentified sports betting operator.\n\nFurthermore, none of the players who are being punished specifically played in any games on which they bet on, and all players denied to the MLB that they had inside information relevant to their wagers. The MLB later said that these were accurate testimonies that aligned with data they received from the sportsbook.\n\nPete Rose, who has been left out of the Hall of Fame, received a lifetime ban in 1989 after he was found to have placed bets on the Cincinnati Reds to win from 1985-1987 while playing for and managing the team.\n\nStay informed! {"uri": "2024-06-378569920", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:04:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:04:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:37:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://fox5sandiego.com/sports/padres/san-diego-padres-tucupita-marcano-banned-for-life-from-mlb-for-sports-betting/", "title": "San Diego Padres' Tucupita Marcano banned for life from MLB for sports betting", "body": "SAN DIEGO (FOX 5/KUSI) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was permanently banned by Major League Baseball officials on Tuesday for violating the league's gambling policy, while four others were placed on a one-year suspension for unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nThe announcement comes one day after the investigation into bets made by the 24-year-old on baseball were made public. According to reports, the alleged sports betting occurred last year while Marcano was on the injured list after sustaining a season-ending ACL injury in July.\n\nOn Tuesday, league officials said their investigation found Marcano had placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers between Oct. 16, 2022 an Nov. 1, 2023. All wagers totaled over $150,000.\n\nAt the time, the infielder was with the Pittsburgh Pirates. He joined the Padres in the offseason on waivers and has spent the first few months of the season on the injured list.\n\nOf the bets he placed, MLB officials said 25 were wagers on Pirates games while he was injured, but still on the team's roster. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nAccording to the league, a legal sportsbook operator tipped off MLB officials about the sports betting activity.\n\nUnder Major League Rule 21, betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official to team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a ban.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was first signed to the Padres as an amateur free agent from Venezuela in 2016. He was traded to the Pirates in 2021 and returned to the Padres on waivers last November.\n\nThe 24-year-old appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nNone of the players punished on Tuesday played in games they bet on, according to league officials. All also denied to MLB that they had inside information relevant to the games they bet on, aligning with the testimony given by the sportsbook operator who tipped off the league.\n\nIn a statement, the Padres officials said they \"cannot comment on violations that occurred outside of our organization,\" but added they \"fully support MLB's sports betting policy and the need to adhere to all provisions of Rule 21.\"\n\n\"We will continue to educate all members of our organization regarding their obligations under the policy,\" the statement continued.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378570464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:04:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:04:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:24:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.orilliamatters.com/national-sports/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year-suspensions-8974789", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\n___\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB\n\nThe Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "orilliamatters.com", Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano, currently a member of the San Diego Padres, was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000.\n\nMLB says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets, according to the league.\n\nRule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leaguers. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego and Jose Rodriguez of Philadelphia were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. {"uri": "8161452446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:18:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:18:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:16:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2961655-mlbs-strict-stance-tucupita-marcano-receives-lifetime-ban", "title": "MLB's Strict Stance: Tucupita Marcano Receives Lifetime Ban | Sports-Games", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been banned for life from Major League Baseball due to placing hundreds of bets on baseball, including games involving his former team, the Pittsburgh Pirates. MLB emphasizes the importance of upholding the integrity of the sport, noting no game outcomes were affected by Marcano's bets.\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano received a lifetime ban from Major League Baseball for placing hundreds of bets on baseball, including games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season when he was a member of the team, MLB said on Tuesday.\n\nAccording to MLB, Marcano did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets as his Pirates-related wagers occurred after he suffered a season-ending knee injury last July. \"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. \"We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nAccording to data obtained from a legal sports betting operator, MLB concluded that Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers from Oct. 16-23, 2022 and from July 12, 2023 through Nov. 1, 2023. In total, MLB said the 24-year-old Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets.\n\nMLB also said there is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way. Marcano first signed with San Diego as an amateur out of Venezuela in 2016 and made his MLB debut in 2021, appearing in 25 games for the club that season before being traded in July of that year to the Pirates.\n\nMarcano had surgery to repair a torn right anterior cruciate ligament that he sustained last July when he awkwardly stepped on third base during a game. The Padres selected Marcano off waivers last November but he had not played for the team since being acquired.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was also suspended one year for betting on MLB games while he was playing in the minor leagues. In addition, MLB said minor league players Jay Groome (Padres pitcher), Jose Rodriguez (Philadelphia Phillies infielder) and Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher) were each banned one year for betting on MLB games.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8160033781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:32:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:32:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:32:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.cp24.com/sports/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says-1.6911786", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, AP source says", "body": "NEW YORK -San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing. Marcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24.\n\nHe was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"\n\n------\n\nAP Sports Writers Greg Beacham and Will Graves contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "cp24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pulse24.com                        "}, "authors": [{"uri": "ronald_blum@cp24.com", "name": "Ronald Blum", "type": "author", {"uri": "2024-06-378582549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:14:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:14:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:04:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://wlos.com/news/entertainment/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year-suspensions-michael-kelly-jay-groome-jos-rodrguez-andrew-saalfrank", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nThe strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.", "source": {"uri": "wlos.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WLOS"}, "authors": [{"uri": The league suspended four other players for one year after finding they placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's MLB's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between 16 October 2022 and 1 November 2023, totaling more than $150,000. However, he did not appear in any of those games after suffering a season-ending knee injury. {"uri": "2024-06-378535183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:33:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:33:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.kcci.com/article/tucupita-marcano-mlb-ban-betting/60992003", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.Marcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.One other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.The league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"Marcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.Major League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMajor League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. {"uri": "2024-06-377683663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:51:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:51:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:20:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/mlb-player-tucupita-marcano-faces-possible-lifetime-ban-for-alleged-baseball-bets-ap-source-says/article_4ebf4359-2855-5724-a91b-70e8b37e42da.html", "title": "MLB player Tucupita Marcano faces possible lifetime ban for alleged baseball bets, AP source says", "body": "FILE - Pittsburgh Pirates shortstop Tucupita Marcano takes a throw down to second base during the fifth inning of a baseball game against the Arizona Diamondbacks, July 7, 2023, in Phoenix. San Diego Padres' Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"\n\nAP Sports Writers Greg Beacham and Will Graves contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: {"uri": "8161493572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:45:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:45:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:45:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.cleveland.com/sports/2024/06/mlb-player-receives-lifetime-ban-for-betting-on-baseball.html", "title": "MLB player receives lifetime ban for betting on baseball", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been permanently banned from Major League Baseball after violating the league's gambling policy, MLB announced Tuesday.\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 bets on baseball, including 231 MLB-related wagers, totaling over $150,000 between Oct. 16, 2022, and Nov. 1, 2023.\n\nHe placed 25 bets on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster in 2023, according to MLB. Marcano did not play in any of those games due to a season-ending knee injury, but was at the Pirates' home PNC Park receiving treatment during the games.\n\nMarcano won 4.3% of his MLB-related bets, according to MLB. He bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay wagers involving the Pirates.\n\nHe is banned under Major League Rule 21, which is posted in each team's clubhouse and states: \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nWith his lifetime suspension, Marcano becomes the first player to be banned under MLB's gambling policy since New York Giants infielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Former Cincinnati Reds star Pete Rose, MLB's leader in career hits, agreed to a lifetime ban from the league in 1989 after an investigation concluded he wagered on Reds games while managing the team from 1984 to 1989.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano, a native of Tucupita, Venezuela, made his MLB debut for the Padres in 2021, appearing in 25 games for the team. He played for the Pirates in 2022 and 2023, hitting .221 in 124 games, before re-signing with the Padres in November 2023. {"uri": "2024-06-377676185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:39:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:39:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:20:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/state_news/mlb-player-tucupita-marcano-faces-possible-lifetime-ban-for-alleged-baseball-bets-ap-source-says/article_64f19dc3-5707-5245-9812-60d4b17ab033.html", "title": "MLB player Tucupita Marcano faces possible lifetime ban for alleged baseball bets, AP source says", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"\n\nAP Sports Writers Greg Beacham and Will Graves contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: {"uri": "8161340152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:02:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:02:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:01:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_3217d4e5-d6b1-5278-8ffa-6ba155e5eff2.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\nTags Wire Dcc Apmediaapi Mlb Gambling Marcano Ban Sports Sports Betting Mlb Baseball Baseball U.s. {"uri": "2024-06-378613145", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:43:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:43:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://qctimes.com/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_5399ace8-5594-5050-b3d9-2e6f41637afe.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been placed under investigation for allegedly violating the MLB's gambling policy. Marcano is being accused of betting on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's injured list last year, according to the Wall Street Journal. \"We are ...\n\nNEW YORK -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport and four others were suspended for one year by Major League Baseball on Tuesday in the game's biggest gambling scandal in decades.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and a three minor leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona, and infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia. Each of those four players wagered under $1,000.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nNASCAR Cup champion Kyle Larson scheduled to race in Davenport on Tuesday The number of concerts at The Mark has declined over its 31 years, here's what's changed Davenport chiropractor sentenced to three years in federal prison for PPP loan fraud Andrew Wold's real estate footprint in Davenport continues to shrink a year after collapse Davenport man arrested for allegedly sexually abusing 6-year-old girl 'We will find you': Moline police arrest man accused of post-prom double murder Two arrested in connection with shooting incident outside of Modern Woodmen Park Eldridge family establishes hospital fund to help other families of children with cancer Friends at opposite ends of the bar react to Trump verdict Davenport spent $3.26M after 324 Main St. collapse; here's where it went Bohonek's hat trick leads Bettendorf to first state title since 1998 Hungry? Here's a list of food trucks in the Quad-Cities to check out Vehicle, body recovered from Mississippi River believed to be missing East Moline man Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Wellington Toffee, Big Strick's Collectibles Police release names of two men injured in officer-involved shooting incident in Muscatine\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they gambled on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nIn its announcement, MLB detailed the bets alleged for each player,\n\nMarcano's 387 baseball bets included 231 MLB-related wagers for $87,319 between Oct. 16, 2022, and last Nov. 1. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. Now 24, Marcano, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park last year.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. The bets included wagers on outcomes, over/under on runs and an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games involved the major league Astros. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, pitched in 21 games for Arizona last year between the regular season and postseason, including three World Series games, and two this year before he was optioned to Triple-A Reno on May 1. He placed 29 baseball bets from Sept. 9 through Oct. 29 in 2021 and on March 9, 2022, including 28 on MLB and one parlay on college baseball. He placed four bets on the big league Diamondbacks while on the injured list of their Low A farm team. His baseball bets totaled $445.87 on baseball, including $444.07 on MLB, and lost $272.64 on MLB bets and $1.80 on the college wager. He won just five of 28 MLB bets, which included outcomes, runs and pitcher strikeouts.\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: International soccer, tennis, baseball and more!\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 29}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Fan_Pages", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Fan Pages", "wgt": 30}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/International", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/International", "wgt": 29}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/History", "wgt": 32}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9621706", "eventUri": "eng-9621706", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-05", "dateEnd": "2024-07-30",
