Discovery"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rob_Manfred", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Rob Manfred"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Supreme Court of the United States"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland,_California", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Oakland, California"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Oakland, California"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 26}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Fan_Pages", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Fan Pages", "wgt": 28}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/International", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/International", "wgt": 26}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/History", "wgt": 28}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Sabermetrics", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Sabermetrics", "wgt": 25}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 59}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/wxow.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/7d/f7d12cfd-82d6-5b14-9e8c-d66b275749d8/665f2f380c905.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9621706", "eventUri": "eng-9621706", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039, "wgt": 201, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-378681933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:50:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:50:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.surreynowleader.com/sports/mlb-bans-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-suspends-4-others-1-year-7370495", "title": "MLB bans Marcano for life for betting on baseball, suspends 4 others 1 year", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport and four others were suspended for one year by Major League Baseball on Tuesday in the game's biggest gambling scandal in decades.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and a three minor leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona, and infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia. Each of those four players wagered under $1,000.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they gambled on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nIn its announcement, MLB detailed the bets alleged for each player,\n\nMarcano's 387 baseball bets included 231 MLB-related wagers for $87,319 between Oct. 16, 2022, and last Nov. 1. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. Now 24, Marcano, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park last year.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. The bets included wagers on outcomes, over/under on runs and an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games involved the major league Astros. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, pitched in 21 games for Arizona last year between the regular season and postseason, including three World Series games, and two this year before he was optioned to Triple-A Reno on May 1. He placed 29 baseball bets from Sept. 9 through Oct. 29 in 2021 and on March 9, 2022, including 28 on MLB and one parlay on college baseball. He placed four bets on the big league Diamondbacks while on the injured list of their Low A farm team. His baseball bets totaled $445.87 on baseball, including $444.07 on MLB, and lost $272.64 on MLB bets and $1.80 on the college wager. He won just five of 28 MLB bets, which included outcomes, runs and pitcher strikeouts.\n\nREAD ALSO: Raptor Jontay Porter banned for life after NBA gambling investigation\n\nREAD ALSO: Ottawa's Pinto We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. {"uri": "8161313832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:44:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:44:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:43:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://wtop.com/mlb/2024/06/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year-suspensions/", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions - WTOP News", "body": "Marcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8160084426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "22:29:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T22:29:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T22:28:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5538064/2024/06/03/tucupita-marcano-ban-betting-mlb-padres/", "title": "MLB investigating Marcano for allegedly gambling on baseball", "body": "MLB is investigating San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for allegedly gambling on baseball, according to a person briefed on the investigation. Marcano is being investigated for betting on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the major-league injured list for them last season, per the source. The MLB penalty for players betting on their own teams is a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, four other players face potential discipline for betting on baseball while playing in the minor leagues, per the source. The names of the four other players are not known at this time. The Wall Street Journal was the first to report the news of the investigations.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the Padres said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMLB and the MLBPA declined to comment.\n\nBaseball's rules forbid players from betting on MLB and minor-league games. Per Rule 21, any player who bets on baseball that doesn't involve his team is suspended for one year and any player who bets on their own team faces a lifetime ban from MLB.\n\nMLB's investigation into Marcano is the latest example of gambling's invasion of pro sports. Los Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter and manager, Ippei Mizuhara, agreed to plead guilty in May to charges of bank fraud for stealing almost $17 million from Ohtani's accounts to cover gambling debts. In April, the NBA banned Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter from the league for betting on the league's games and sharing inside information.\n\nThe most notable example of a lifetime ban from MLB was career-hits leader Pete Rose. An MLB investigation found he bet on games as a player and manager for the Cincinnati Reds from 1985 to 1987.\n\nMarcano, 24, hasn't played since July 24, 2023, due to a torn right ACL. In 2023, he slashed .233/.276/.356 with three home runs and 18 RBIs.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161133927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "12:53:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T12:53:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T12:50:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1327345", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano faces MLB ban for betting", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is facing a potential lifetime ban for betting on baseball after Major League Baseball received information that he wagered on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates when he was with the team last season, sources confirmed to ESPN on Monday.\n\nMarcano, 24, has yet to be formally penalized, but MLB Rule 21 explicitly states that a player who bets on games involving his own team is subject to a lifetime ban. Marcano tore an ACL last year and was on the injured list when he allegedly placed the bets, which were flagged by a sportsbook and reported to the league, according to sources.\n\nThe potential ban of Marcano comes in the wake of the NBA handing down a ban to Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter for disclosing confidential information to bettors, limiting his participation in at least one game and betting on NBA games while playing in the G League.\n\nFour other minor league players are facing potential discipline for betting as well, sources told ESPN. Even if a player in the minor leagues is on a team's 40-man roster, he would face a one-year suspension for betting on major league games, according to Rule 21.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal first reported the looming discipline for all five players.\n\nAs pervasive as betting in sports has become, it is particularly sensitive in baseball, a sport whose hit king, Pete Rose, remains banned for betting, and whose championship series was thrown in 1919 by the Chicago White Sox. Los Angeles Dodgers superstar Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, has indicated he plans to plead guilty to federal felony charges after admitting he had stolen money from Ohtani to pay off gambling debts.\n\nMLB continues to investigate Ohtani's former teammate with the Los Angeles Angels, David Fletcher, for betting on sports with the same illegal bookmaker who took wagers from Mizuhara, according to ESPN's Tisha Thompson.\n\nMarcano's case, about which MLB and the MLB Players Association continue to discuss the ultimate discipline, would represent the first direct penalty for a player betting on baseball since Rose. In 2015, Miami Marlins right-hander Jarred Cosart was fined for placing bets not on baseball but with an illegal bookmaker.\n\nSince the Supreme Court's 2018 ruling that began the spread of legal betting in the U.S., 12 NFL players, an assistant coach and an undisclosed number of league personnel have been suspended for violating the gambling policy, in addition to Porter's banishment from the NBA.\n\nMLB and the MLBPA declined comment, as did Marcano through his agent. Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki told ESPN: \"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating. We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Padres said: \"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano rejoined the Padres this winter as a waiver claim after they had sent him to Pittsburgh at the 2021 trade deadline in a deal for infielder Adam Frazier. In 149 career games, Marcano hit .217/.269/.320 with five home runs and seven stolen bases in 447 plate appearances.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-377648800", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:53:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:53:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:35:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.bradfordera.com/sports/national/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says/article_dab49d2d-37c6-5143-a089-ca169ddb0b20.html", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, AP source says", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nAP Sports Writer Greg Beacham contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/mlb", "source": {"uri": "bradfordera.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8161537815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:19:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:19:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:19:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://time.com/6985479/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-betting-baseball/", "title": "MLB Bans Tucupita Marcano for Life for Betting on Baseball", "body": "NEW YORK -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport and four others were suspended for one year by Major League Baseball on Tuesday in the game's biggest gambling scandal in decades.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and three minor leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona, and infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia. Each of those four players wagered under $1,000. Saalfrank and Rodr\u00edguez played previously in the majors.\n\nRead More: MLB Expands Aid Programs to Support Living Negro Leagues Players\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano is the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off in March about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they gambled on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nRead More: 3 Australian League Soccer Players Arrested Over Alleged Yellow Card-Fixing Scheme\n\nIn its announcement, MLB detailed the bets alleged for each player.\n\nMarcano's 387 baseball bets included international games and 231 MLB-related wagers for $87,319 between Oct. 16, 2022, and last Nov. 1. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. Now 24, Marcano, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park last year.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\n\"While the thorough investigation revealed no evidence of any games being compromised, influenced or manipulated in any way in this case, protecting the integrity of our game is paramount,\" the Pirates said in a statement.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. The bets included wagers on outcomes, over/under on runs and an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games involved the major league Astros. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, pitched in 21 games for Arizona last year between the regular season and postseason, including three World Series games, and two this year before he was optioned to Triple-A Reno on May 1. He placed 29 baseball bets from Sept. 9 through Oct. 29 in 2021 and on March 9, 2022, including 28 on MLB and one parlay on college baseball. He placed four bets on the big league Diamondbacks while on the injured list of their Low A farm team. His baseball bets totaled $445.87 on baseball, including $444.07 on MLB, and lost $272.64 on MLB bets and $1.80 on the college wager. He won just five of 28 MLB bets, which included outcomes, runs and pitcher strikeouts.", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161515356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:03:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:03:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:02:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/sport/international/a/2201778.html", "title": "San Diego Padres infielder Marcano banned for life for gambling", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been banned for life from Major League Baseball for betting on games, the league announced on Tuesday.\n\nMichael Kelly, a pitcher for the Oakland Athletics, and three minor league players were also suspended for a year for gambling on baseball games, MLB said.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Robert Manfred said in a statement.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century,\" Manfred said. \"We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMLB said Marcano, who has been on the injured list this season recovering from ACL surgery, has been declared \"permanently ineligible\" for violating the league's sports betting rules and policies.\n\nIt said the 24-year-old Venezuelan-born Padres player placed 387 bets on baseball in 2022 and 2023, including 231 bets on MLB games through a legal sportsbook.\n\n\"In total, Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets,\" it said.\n\nMarcano, who was playing for the Pittsburgh Pirates at the time, \"did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets,\" the league said.\n\n\"There is no evidence to suggest -- - and Marcano denies -- - that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\"\n\nKelly, 31, the Oakland Athletics pitcher suspended for a year, placed 10 bets totaling $99.22 on MLB games in 2021 while he was with a minor league affiliate of the Houston Astros, MLB said.\n\n\"Kelly did not appear in any of the games on which he bet, and he did not make any bets involving his assigned team,\" the league said.\n\nKelly has appeared in 28 games for the A's this year, pitching 31.1 innings and sporting a 2.59 ERA.\n\n- Ohtani interpreter -\n\nThe other three players suspended for a year are Jay Groome, a pitcher for a Padres minor league affiliate, Jose Rodriguez, an infielder in the Philadelphia Phillies organization, and Andrew Saalfrank, a pitcher for an Arizona Diamondbacks minor league team.\n\nGroome, 25, made 32 MLB-related bets in 2020 and 2021 totaling around $450, the league said, none of which involved his team.\n\nRodriguez, 23, bet around $750 in 2021 and 2022 on 28 MLB and three college baseball games -- none of which involved him as a player, MLB said.\n\nAs for Saalfrank, 26, he bet $445 on 28 MLB games and one college game, and did not appear in any of the games on which he placed wagers.\n\nMLB was rocked earlier this year by revelations that the former interpreter of Shohei Ohtani had stolen nearly $17 million from the Los Angeles Dodgers star's bank account to pay off gambling debts.\n\nAccording to federal prosecutors, Ippei Mizuhara -- Ohtani's long-time friend and confidant -- plundered the Japanese player's bank account to fund an \"insatiable appetite\" for gambling.\n\nThe life ban for Marcano comes nearly two months after the National Basketball Association banned Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter for life for betting on NBA games.", "source": {"uri": "today.rtl.lu", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTL Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-06-378659382", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:27:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:27:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:54:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/06/04/former-nj-high-school-superstar-caught-up-in-mlb-betting-investigation/", "title": "Former NJ high school superstar caught up in MLB betting investigation", "body": "Jay Groome, a former first-round pick of the Red Sox, banned for one season\n\nNEW YORK -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport and four others were suspended for one year by Major League Baseball on Tuesday in the game's biggest gambling scandal in decades.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and a three minor leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona, and infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia. Each of those four players wagered under $1,000.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they gambled on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nIn its announcement, MLB detailed the bets alleged for each player,\n\nMarcano's 387 baseball bets included 231 MLB-related wagers for $87,319 between Oct. 16, 2022, and last Nov. 1. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. Now 24, Marcano, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park last year.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. The bets included wagers on outcomes, over/under on runs and an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games involved the major league Astros. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, pitched in 21 games for Arizona last year between the regular season and postseason, including three World Series games, and two this year before he was optioned to Triple-A Reno on May 1. He placed 29 baseball bets from Sept. 9 through Oct. 29 in 2021 and on March 9, 2022, including 28 on MLB and one parlay on college baseball. He placed four bets on the big league Diamondbacks while on the injured list of their Low A farm team. His baseball bets totaled $445.87 on baseball, including $444.07 on MLB, and lost $272.64 on MLB bets and $1.80 on the college wager. He won just five of 28 MLB bets, which included outcomes, runs and pitcher strikeouts.", "source": {"uri": "trentonian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Trentonian"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161443495", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:10:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:10:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:09:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.readingeagle.com/2024/06/04/fightin-phils-player-suspended-for-one-year-for-betting-on-baseball/", "title": "Fightin Phils player suspended for one year for betting on baseball", "body": "Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez, 23, of the Reading Fightin Phils was suspended by Major League Baseball on Tuesday for one year for betting on baseball games.\n\nAn investigation found that Rodriguez placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nRodriguez was one of four players suspended for a year.\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and two other minor-leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big-league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team. Major League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.", "source": {"uri": "8161532997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:16:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:16:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:15:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.westernjournal.com/padres-24-year-old-shortstop-banned-life-gambling/", "title": "Padres' 24-Year-Old Shortstop Banned for Life for Gambling", "body": "Major League Baseball handed San Diego Padres shortstop Tucupita Marcano a lifetime ban on Tuesday after he was found to have violated the league's policy on gambling.\n\nThe announcement followed an investigation into the 24-year-old that found he wagered on more than 200 MLB games, including some that involved the Pittsburgh Pirates during the 2022 and 2023 seasons when he was on the team, ESPN reported.\n\nMarcano was acquired by San Diego last fall.\n\nIn total, the league said Marcano placed 387 bets related to baseball, with 231 of them on MLB games.\n\nMarcano wagered a total of $150,000 on the contests between October 2022 and November 2023.\n\nTwenty-five of the bets involved his own team -- the Pirates -- while he was on the roster but was recovering from surgery for a torn ACL.\n\nHe did not play in any of the games in which he had placed bets and lost each parlay wager that included his own team.\n\nMarcano was said to have ultimately won on 4.3 percent of all bets he placed on the outcomes of MLB games.\n\nHis decision to wager on the games cost him much more than the money he lost as he will never suit up for another team again.\n\nIn a statement, MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said that banning Marcano was crucial to protecting the integrity of the game.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Manfred stated.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century,\" the commissioner concluded. \"We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nBaseball clubs are clear with players that gambling on the sport they play is strictly prohibited and what the outcome will be.\n\nPer ESPN, it is believed Marcano is the first active player in 100 years to be handed a lifetime ban.\n\nIn 1924, then-New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell was also banned for life after he was found to have wagered on games.\n\nPete Rose was given a lifetime ban for gambling in 1989, but it was three years after he retired while he was managing the Cincinnati Reds.\n\nMarcano's bets were reportedly discovered when a \"legal sports betting operator\" reached out to the league to alert MLB officials.\n\nThe Venezuelan national was not the only player punished on Tuesday, but he was the only one to be given a lifetime ban.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was handed a one-year suspension for placing bets on MLB games while he was in the minors.\n\nAdditionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome, Jose Rodriguez and Andrew Saalfrank were all suspended for one year.\n\nEvery player punished on Tuesday denied betting on any games "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/baseball/articles/ce774146pr3o", "title": "Major League Baseball: Tucupita Marcano gets life ban for betting on own team's games", "body": "Major League Baseball infielder Tucupita Marcano has been banned for life for placing hundreds of bets on the sport - including on his own team's games.\n\nThe 24-year-old was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets from October 2022 to November 2023, while he was a Pittsburgh Pirates player.\n\nMarcano, who has not played this season because of a knee injury, did not appear in any of the games concerned which came before he began a second spell with the San Diego Padres last November.\n\nIn total, MLB said Marcano bet more than $150,000 (\u00a3117,322.50) on baseball, with $87,319 (\u00a368,296.56) of that on MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano denies that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced or manipulated in any way.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, who separately placed bets on nine MLB games, has been banned for one year.\n\nThe 31-year-old Kelly bet a total of $99.22 (\u00a377.60) for a net win of $28.30 (\u00a322.13) from those bets.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\nMLB launched an investigation into gambling after receiving information from sports betting companies.\n\nThe last active player to receive a lifetime ban for gambling had been New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924.\n\nThree minor league players have received bans for breaching the betting rules, with Padres pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies infielder Jose Rodriguez and Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher Andrew Saalfrank all declared ineligible for one as sport is rocked by another gambling scandal", "body": "READ MORE: Shohei Ohtani gambling scandal being turned into TV series\n\nSan Diego Padres star Tucupita Marcano is facing a potential lifetime ban from MLB for betting on baseball games in 2023, as yet another gambling scandal rocks the sport.\n\nA league investigation subjecting the 24-year-old Marcano is underway, according to The Wall Street Journal on Monday, months after LA Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani was accused of wiring $4.5million to a California bookmaking operation in March.\n\nMarcano - an infielder - was placed on the injured list by the Pittsburgh Pirates in July of last year and underwent surgery to repair the anterior crucial ligament in his right knee.\n\nThe Padres signed him off waivers in November, but Marcano has yet to play this season, as he still is recovering from surgery.\n\nPer the WSJ report, Marcano 'has been accused of betting on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season while he was on the injured list for that team.'\n\nTucupita Marcano has been subjected to an MLB investigation for betting on MLB games in '23\n\nPer the report, the league and the MLB Players' Association are currently discussing a suitable punishment for Marcano's betting offense, and a lifetime ban could be on the cards.\n\nMLB, Marcano, and the players' union have yet to comment on the report, though the Padres released a statement.\n\n'We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres.\n\n'We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.'\n\nThe 24-year-old infielder last played in July '23 for Pittsburgh. He signed with San Diego in Nov.\n\nIf proven guilty, Marcano will become the biggest name in baseball to be banned from the sport since Pete Rose in 1989.\n\nMarcano last played on July 24, 2023, when he started at second base for the Pirates. He left the game in the fifth inning after an ACL injury to his right knee while running bases.\n\nHe made his major league debut in 2021, five years after signing with the Padres as a 16-year-old out {"uri": "2024-06-378625940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:55:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:55:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:15:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.capitalgazette.com/2024/06/04/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year-suspensions/", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport and four others were suspended for one year by Major League Baseball on Tuesday in the game's biggest gambling scandal in decades.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and a three minor leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona, and infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia. Each of those four players wagered under $1,000.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they gambled on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nIn its announcement, MLB detailed the bets alleged for each player,\n\nMarcano's 387 baseball bets included 231 MLB-related wagers for $87,319 between Oct. 16, 2022, and last Nov. 1. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. Now 24, Marcano, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park last year.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. The bets included wagers on outcomes, over/under on runs and an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games involved the major league Astros. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, pitched in 21 games for Arizona last year between the regular season and postseason, including three World Series games, and two this year before he was optioned to Triple-A Reno on May 1. He placed 29 baseball bets from Sept. 9 through Oct. 29 in 2021 and on March 9, 2022, including 28 on MLB and one parlay on college baseball. He placed four bets on the big league Diamondbacks while on the injured list of their Low A farm team. His baseball bets totaled $445.87 on baseball, including $444.07 on MLB, and lost $272.64 on MLB bets and $1.80 on the college wager. He won just five of 28 MLB bets, which included outcomes, runs and pitcher strikeouts.", "source": {"uri": "capitalgazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Capital Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161396237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:39:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:39:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:37:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_3f7d9d38-5c16-5f50-8281-c2ef5c7624cf.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport and four others were suspended for one year by Major League Baseball on Tuesday in the game's biggest gambling scandal in decades.\n\nMLB said Marcano placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was suspended for one year for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues and a three minor leaguers also were banned for one year for betting on big league games: pitchers Jay Groome of San Diego and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona, and infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia. Each of those four players wagered under $1,000.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nMarcano was the first active major leaguer banned for life under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano became the second North American athlete banned for gambling in recent months. The NBA gave Toronto's Jontay Porter a lifetime ban in April after concluding he disclosed confidential information to bettors and wagered on games, including on the Raptors to lose.\n\nMLB said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they gambled on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nIn its announcement, MLB detailed the bets alleged for each player,\n\nMarcano's 387 baseball bets included 231 MLB-related wagers for $87,319 between Oct. 16, 2022, and last Nov. 1. Twenty-five of those bets included wagers on Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. Now 24, Marcano, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park last year.\n\nMarcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nThe other four players did not bet on games involving their assigned teams.\n\nKelly placed 10 bets on nine major league games from Oct. 5-17, 2021, while a minor league player assigned to Houston's Triple-A Sugar Land farm team. The bets included wagers on outcomes, over/under on runs and an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games involved the major league Astros. His wagers totaled $99.22 and resulted in $28.30 of winnings.\n\nKelly, 31, was 3-2 with a 2.59 ERA in 28 games this season, last pitching on Saturday at Atlanta. The former first-round draft pick appeared in 46 games over the past three seasons.\n\nGroome, a 25-year-old who had been on a minor league injured list since mid-April, placed 32 MLB-related bets from July 22, 2020, through July 24, 2021, including 24 on the Boston Red Sox major league team while he was assigned to Boston's High-A team in Greenville, South Carolina. The sport detailed he wagered $453.74 on 30 MLB games and had a net loss of $433.54, receiving payouts on only two wagers. His betting included parlays.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, 23, has been at Double-A Reading this season. He placed 31 bets on baseball on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5 through July 30 in 2022, including 28 on MLB and three on college baseball. The total included seven involving the Chicago White Sox at the time he was assigned to their Double-A team in Birmingham, Alabama. Two of the White Sox bets involved outcomes and the others were on runs scored. He bet $749.09 on baseball, of which $724.09 was on MLB-related bets that included parlays.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, pitched in 21 games for Arizona last year between the regular season and postseason, including three World Series games, and two this year before he was optioned to Triple-A Reno on May 1. He placed 29 baseball bets from Sept. 9 through Oct. 29 in 2021 and on March 9, 2022, including 28 on MLB and one parlay on college baseball. He placed four bets on the big league Diamondbacks while on the injured list of their Low A farm team. His baseball bets totaled $445.87 on baseball, including $444.07 on MLB, and lost $272.64 on MLB bets and $1.80 on the college wager. He won just five of 28 MLB bets, which included outcomes, runs and pitcher strikeouts.\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: International soccer, tennis, baseball and more!\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. ban for betting on baseball", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been permanently banned from Major League Baseball for placing hundred of bets on baseball, including games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season when he was a member of the team, MLB said on Tuesday.\n\nAccording to MLB, Marcano did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets as his Pirates-related wagers occurred after he suffered a season-ending knee injury last July.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century.\n\n\"We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nAccording to data obtained from a legal sports betting operator, MLB concluded that Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers from Oct. 16-23, 2022 and from July 12, 2023 through Nov. 1, 2023.\n\nIn total, MLB said Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets.\n\nMLB also said there is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, {"uri": "8160007591", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:05:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:05:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com/stories/mlb/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano reportedly under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to multiple reports.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to The Associated Press. The investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, {"uri": "8160004469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:02:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:02:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/mlb/news/report-padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball", "title": "Report: Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball", "body": "NEW YORK -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to reports.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. {"uri": "8161427158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:01:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:01:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:59:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/sports/2024/06/padres-infielder-banned-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball.html", "title": "Padres infielder banned for life for betting on baseball", "body": "Baseball's latest betting scandal has an active player looking at a lifetime ban from Major League Baseball.\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been banned for life from MLB, the league announced on Tuesday.\n\nFour other players received one-year bans in addition to Marcano's punishment.\n\nAccording to MLB, Marcano in two different periods in 2022 and 2023, Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 on MLB via a legal sportsbook. Twenty-five of those bets were related to the Pittsburgh Pirates, the team he played for at the time, although he did not appear in any games he bet on (Marcano suffered a season-ending ACL injury on July 24, 2023.\n\nPlacing mostly parlay bets, Marcano lost all of his wagers involving the Pirates and won 4.3 percent of his MLB bets overall. Those bets totaled more than $87,000.\n\nMarcano denies that he influenced the outcomes of any games, according to MLB.\n\nSigned by the Padres as a free agent in 2016, Marcano played 149 total games in three seasons with the Padres and Pirates. He had yet to play in 2024 due to his knee injury.\n\nOakland athletic reliever Michael Kelly also received a one-year ban, as did minor leaguers Jay Groome (Padres), Jose Rodriguez (Phillies) and {"uri": "8160076336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "22:19:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T22:19:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T22:18:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/mlb/tucupita-marcano-faces-possible-lifetime-ban-alleged-gambling-1.7223435", "title": "MLB infielder Tucupita Marcano faces possible lifetime ban for alleged gambling | CBC Sports", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [],
