{"uri": "2024-06-378575927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:09:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:09:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_2ba9aed0-7533-5785-ab0f-10c1dcdc2b02.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been placed under investigation for allegedly violating the MLB's gambling policy. Marcano is being accused of betting on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's injured list last year, according to the Wall Street Journal. \"We are ...\n\nNEW YORK -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nOne killed, one injured in I-380 motorcycle accident Saturday night at Waterloo Reinbeck man detained after search turns up gun, cash, drugs Waterloo man arrested in teen-enticing sting Deere to lay off global production, salaried employees at end of third quarter Iowa restaurant inspection update: Green slime, moldy meat, unlicensed eateries Father arrested for leaving children home alone, blaming mother Waterloo council could turn old church into housing, day care Man arrested for allegedly stealing Waterloo school district truck New paws on the block: Waterloo Police welcome two new K-9s to the force Masic, Neff vie for Black Hawk County sheriff's position in Tuesday's primary election Fire destroys garage and vehicles in Waterloo Overnight shooting damages Waterloo home; no injuries reported Iowa Supreme Court overturns conviction in 2020 fatal shooting Part I: The Right Coach Waterloo police arrest man for literally being a cat burglar\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Stanley Cup and NBA playoffs, baseball, soccer and more!\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161419633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:54:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:54:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:53:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/06/04/mlb-hits-tucupita-marcano-with-lifetime-ban-for-betting-on-baseball-games.html", "title": "MLB hits Tucupita Marcano with lifetime ban for betting on baseball games", "body": "Infielder Tucupita Marcano #16 of the San Diego Padres slides and scores against the Arizona Diamondbacks on Opening Day at Petco Park on April 1, 2021 in San Diego, California.\n\nMajor League Baseball banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on the sport, officials said Tuesday, making him the first active player hit with such a penalty in more than a century.\n\nThe 24-year-old Venezuelan broke into MLB in 2021 with the Padres before he was traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates, released and picked up by the Friars again this past off season.\n\nHe hadn't appeared in a game this season, recovering from a knee injury.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano bet through a legal sports book with wagers coming in two spans of time -- in 2022, from Oct. 16 through Oct. 23, and again in 2023 from July 12 through Nov. 1, according to MLB.\n\nHe made a total of 387 bets on both domestic and international baseball, with 231 of those wagers on MLB action, the league said. The bets were for a total of more than $150,000 with $87,319 of that action on MLB games, the league added.\n\nAnd of those MLB bets, 25 involved Pirates games while Marcano was with the Bucs, though he did not appear in any of those contests.\n\nIn fact, a \"vast majority\" of Marcano's wagers \"occurred during the period after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023 and was receiving medical treatment,\" MLB said.\n\nThe last active player kicked out baseball for gambling was New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924.\n\nPete Rose, MLB's career leader in base hits, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after he was found to have wagered on baseball games while managing the Cincinnati Reds.\n\nMLB on Tuesday also announced one-year suspensions for other players it found in violation of league gambling prohibitions.", "source": {"uri": "cnbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNBC"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_k_li@cnbc.com", "name": "David K. {"uri": "8161312579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:43:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:43:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:42:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/baseball/padres-tucupita-marcano-lifetime-ban-gambling/634070", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano receives lifetime ban for gambling on own team", "body": "May 5, 2023; Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA; Pittsburgh Pirates shortstop Tucupita Marcano (30) prior to the game against the Toronto Blue Jays at PNC Park. Mandatory Credit: Gregory Fisher-USA TODAY Sports\n\nMajor League Baseball announced on Tuesday that San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been permanently banned from the league for gambling on baseball.\n\nIn a press release, MLB revealed that an investigation determined that Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 worth of the wagers involving MLB games. Marcano placed the bets over a period of a week in October 2022 and a roughly four-month span from July 2023 to November 2023.\n\nMarcano placed more than 200 bets involving MLB games, with 25 of the bets involving the Pittsburgh Pirates when Marcano was on the team's Major League roster. According to investigators, \"almost all\" of Marcano's bets on the Pirates involved Pittsburgh winning or the over/under run total in his team's games. There is no evidence to suggest that the outcome of any of the games on which Marcano placed bets was influenced.\n\nIn total, MLB determined that Marcano placed 231 MLB-related wagers and won just 4.3% of them.\n\nMLB also announced that four other players -- Oakland Athletics reliever Michael Kelly, Padres minor-league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor-league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez, and Arizona Diamondbacks minor-league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank -- have each been banned one year for unrelated violations of the league's gambling policy.\n\nBetting on baseball is strictly prohibited by MLB rules. Players found to have bet on their own team face a lifetime ban, while those who bet on other teams can be suspended for up to a year. Betting on sports other than baseball is permitted as long as the bets are placed legally. At least one player is being investigated for involvement with the same illegal bookie that ensnared Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter.\n\nMarcano, 24, played parts of three seasons in MLB with the Padres and Pirates. He was a career .217 hitter and had generally been used as a backup utility infielder since making his debut in 2021. {"uri": "8160013538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:11:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:11:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:09:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.espn.com.au/mlb/story/_/id/40271458/sources-padres-tucupita-marcano-faces-mlb-ban-betting", "title": "Sources: Padres' Marcano faces ban for betting", "body": "ESPN MLB insider\n\nAuthor of \"The Arm: Inside the Billion-Dollar Mystery of the Most Valuable Commodity in Sports\"\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is facing a potential lifetime ban for betting on baseball after Major League Baseball received information that he wagered on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates when he was with the team last season, sources confirmed to ESPN on Monday.\n\nMarcano, 24, has yet to be formally penalized, but MLB Rule 21 explicitly states that a player who bets on games involving his own team is subject to a lifetime ban. Marcano tore his ACL last year and was on the injured list when he allegedly placed the bets, which were flagged by a sportsbook and reported to the league, according to sources.\n\nThe potential ban of Marcano comes in the wake of the NBA handing down a lifetime penalty to Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter for disclosing confidential information to bettors, limiting his participation in at least one game and betting on NBA games while in the minor leagues.\n\nFour other minor league players are facing potential discipline for gambling as well, sources told ESPN. Even if a player in the minor leagues is on a team's 40-man roster, he would face a one-year suspension for gambling on major league games, according to Rule 21.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal first reported the looming discipline for all five players.\n\nAs pervasive as gambling in sports has become, it is particularly sensitive in baseball, a sport whose championship series was thrown in 1919 by the Chicago White Sox and whose hit king, Pete Rose, remains banned for gambling. Los Angeles Dodgers superstar Shohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, pleaded guilty in May to federal felony charges after admitting he had stolen money from Ohtani to pay off gambling debts.\n\nMLB continues to investigate Ohtani's former teammate with the Los Angeles Angels, David Fletcher, for betting on sports with the same illegal bookmaker who took wagers from Mizuhara, according to ESPN's Tisha Thompson.\n\nMarcano's case, about which MLB and the MLB Players Association continue to discuss the ultimate discipline, would represent the first direct penalty for a player betting on baseball since Rose. In 2015, Miami Marlins right-hander Jarred Cosart was fined for placing bets not on baseball but with an illegal bookmaker.\n\nMLB and the MLBPA declined comment, as did Marcano through his agent. Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki told ESPN: \"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating. We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Padres said: \"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano rejoined the Padres this winter as a waiver claim after they had sent him to Pittsburgh at the 2021 trade deadline in a trade for infielder Adam Frazier. In 149 career games, Marcano hit .217/.269/.320 with five home runs and seven stolen bases in 447 plate appearances.\n\nSince the Supreme Court's 2018 ruling that began the spread of legal betting in the U.S., 12 NFL players, an assistant coach and an undisclosed number of league personnel have been suspended for violating the gambling policy, in addition to Porter's banishment from the NBA.", {"uri": "8159999619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:56:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:56:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:55:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/40271458/sources-padres-tucupita-marcano-faces-mlb-ban-betting", "title": "Sources: Padres' Marcano faces ban for betting", "body": "ESPN MLB insider\n\nAuthor of \"The Arm: Inside the Billion-Dollar Mystery of the Most Valuable Commodity in Sports\"\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is facing a potential lifetime ban for betting on baseball after Major League Baseball received information that he wagered on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates when he was with the team last season, sources confirmed to ESPN on Monday.\n\nMarcano, 24, has yet to be formally penalized, but MLB Rule 21 explicitly states that a player who bets on games involving his own team is subject to a lifetime ban. Marcano tore his ACL last year and was on the injured list when he allegedly placed the bets, which were flagged by a sportsbook and reported to the league, according to sources.\n\nThe potential ban of Marcano comes in the wake of the NBA handing down a lifetime penalty to Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter for disclosing confidential information to bettors, limiting his participation in at least one game and betting on NBA games while in the minor leagues.\n\nFour other minor league players are facing potential discipline for gambling as well, sources told ESPN. Even if a player in the minor leagues is on a team's 40-man roster, he would face a one-year suspension for gambling on major league games, according to Rule 21.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal first reported the looming discipline for all five players.\n\nAs pervasive as gambling in sports has become, it is particularly sensitive in baseball, a sport whose championship series was thrown in 1919 by the Chicago White Sox and whose hit king, Pete Rose, remains banned for gambling. Los Angeles Dodgers superstar Shohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, pleaded guilty in May to federal felony charges after admitting he had stolen money from Ohtani to pay off gambling debts.\n\nMLB continues to investigate Ohtani's former teammate with the Los Angeles Angels, David Fletcher, for betting on sports with the same illegal bookmaker who took wagers from Mizuhara, according to ESPN's Tisha Thompson.\n\nMarcano's case, about which MLB and the MLB Players Association continue to discuss the ultimate discipline, would represent the first direct penalty for a player betting on baseball since Rose. In 2015, Miami Marlins right-hander Jarred Cosart was fined for placing bets not on baseball but with an illegal bookmaker.\n\nMLB and the MLBPA declined comment, as did Marcano through his agent. Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki told ESPN: \"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating. We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Padres said: \"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano rejoined the Padres this winter as a waiver claim after they had sent him to Pittsburgh at the 2021 trade deadline in a trade for infielder Adam Frazier. In 149 career games, Marcano hit .217/.269/.320 with five home runs and seven stolen bases in 447 plate appearances.", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. {"uri": "8161338946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:02:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:02:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:00:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/chicago/news/tucupita-marcano-betting-baseball-games-ban/", "title": "Tucupita Marcano permanently banned from baseball for violating MLB's gambling policy", "body": "PITTSBURGH (KDKA) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano, a former Pittsburgh Pirate, is now permanently banned from MLB for violating the league's gambling policy, the league announced Tuesday morning.\n\nFour other players are facing year-long suspensions including Oakland A's pitcher Michael Kelly, San Diego Padres's pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies' infielder Jose Rodriguez and Arizona Diamondbacks' player Andrew Saalfrank.\n\nIn March of 2024, through a legal sports betting operator, past betting activity from MLB players occurred. The MLB states that no player placed a bet in a game they played in.\n\nAccording to the league's statement, Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets through a legal sportsbook. His bets consisted of parlays that would include MLB-related legs. Marcano bet over $150,000 on baseball, $87,319 of which were on MLB-related bets specifically.\n\nThrough the investigation, the MLB found that 25 of his 200 bets included Pittsburgh Pirates games when he was on the major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of the games he gambled on.\n\nMarcano lost all of the parlays involving the Pirates and only won 4.3% of his MLB-related bets overall, the league said.\n\nMarcano appeared in 75 games for the Pirates last season. In August 2023, Marcano underwent season-ending surgery to repair a torn right ACL.\n\nIn a statement to CBS News, the Pirates said, \"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating. We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's punishment, which has not been finalized, hinges on negotiations between MLB and the Major League Baseball Players Association, according to the Wall Street Journal. In a statement to CBS News, the MLBPA said, \"We will not be commenting on this.\"\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the San Diego Padres said in a statement to CBS News. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano made his major league debut in 2021 with the Padres before playing two seasons in Pittsburgh. {"uri": "2024-06-377668330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:24:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:24:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:45:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says/article_1ba7c817-f8c0-5a33-a952-65c3377ef3ea.html", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, AP source says", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nAP Sports Writer Greg Beacham contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/mlb\n\nMore from this section\n\nDovenmuehle announces strategic business development promotions to support demand for its mortgage subservicing offerings\n\nCEOs got hefty pay raises in 2023, widening the gap with the workers they oversee\n\nDestination: {"uri": "8160330623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "03:28:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T03:28:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T03:27:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/san-diego-padres-infielder-tucupita-marcano-reportedly-could-face-lifetime-ban-for-betting-on-baseball-200000428.html", "title": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano reportedly could face lifetime ban for betting on baseball", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is facing a potential lifetime ban from Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on games, according to The Wall Street Journal.\n\nMarcano allegedly bet on multiple games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season when he was on their injured list. Specifics of those bets aren't yet known. Four other players are also reportedly under investigation for allegedly betting on games in the minor leagues, too.\n\nThough the investigation into Marcano is still ongoing, a decision on the potential lifetime ban \"could be imminent,\" according to ESPN's Jeff Passan:\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played for the Padres this season. He went down with a right ACL injury in 2023 when he was with the Pirates, and he's been recovering ever since. According to the report, Marcano bet on Pirates games only after he went down with the injury.\n\nThe Padres, who first signed him out of Venezuela and gave him his major league start in 2021, then signed him to a one-year deal this past offseason.\n\nMarcano, the league and the Players Association all declined to comment to The Wall Street Journal.\n\nMarcano held a career-high .233 batting average last season with the Pirates. He had 18 RBI, 47 hits and three home runs in 75 games. He tore his ACL in late July, and missed the rest of the season as a result.\n\nThe gambling allegations against Marcano are just the latest in the league and the sports world in general in recent months. Los Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter pleaded guilty to charges after he reportedly stole nearly $17 million from Ohtani to cover his illegal gambling losses. Ohtani was not involved in that scandal, which dominated the sport in the lead-up to the season.\n\nToronto Raptors player Jontay Porter was given a lifetime ban from the NBA earlier this year, too, after the league said he purposely limited his participation in games for betting purposes and for betting on games. Porter, who is the brother of Denver Nuggets star Michael Porter Jr., was on a two-way deal with the franchise.\n\nWest Ham midfielder Lucas Paquet\u00e1 was charged by the English Football Association for allegedly breaching their betting rules last month. Former Alabama baseball coach Brad Bohannon was fired after a friend of his tried to make a $100,000 bet on the team. The NFL has cracked down on gambling, too, as several players have been hit with suspensions for violating gambling rules either while in the league or while in college.\n\nLike in the NFL, Major League Baseball's gambling policy prohibits players from placing any bets on baseball. They are allowed to bet on other sports legally. Any player who places a wager on a baseball game involving a team other than their own receives a one-year suspension, but betting on your own team leads to a lifetime ban.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8159990112", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:46:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:46:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:45:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/06/03/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says/", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, AP source says - Medicine Hat News", "body": "SUBSCRIBE NOW NEW YORK (AP) - San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe. MLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing. Marcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19. MLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal. \"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\"\u009d the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\u009d Marcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment. Major League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban. In addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner. Career hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team. The last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27. Marcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield. ___ AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham contributed to this report. ___ AP MLB:", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8161571831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:45:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:45:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:45:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb-player-given-life-ban-165938279.html", "title": "MLB player given life ban for betting on own team", "body": "Major League Baseball infielder Tucupita Marcano has been banned for life for placing hundreds of bets on the sport - including on his own team's games.\n\nThe 24-year-old was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets from October 2022 to November 2023, while he was a Pittsburgh Pirates player.\n\nMarcano, who has not played this season because of a knee injury, did not appear in any of the games concerned which came before he began a second spell with the San Diego Padres last November.\n\nIn total, MLB said Marcano bet more than $150,000 (\u00a3117,322.50) on baseball, with $87,319 (\u00a368,296.56) of that on MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano denies that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced or manipulated in any way.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, who separately placed bets on nine MLB games, has been banned for one year.\n\nThe 31-year-old Kelly bet a total of $99.22 (\u00a377.60) for a net win of $28.30 (\u00a322.13) from those bets.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\nMLB launched an investigation into gambling after receiving information from sports betting companies.\n\nThe last active player to receive a lifetime ban for gambling had been New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8160044372", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:44:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:44:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:44:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/sports/baseball/mlb-player-tucupita-marcano-faces-possible-lifetime-ban-for-alleged-baseball-bets-ap-source-says/article_d6962d50-d5eb-56c4-bac0-fc3d7e223c2f.html", "title": "MLB player Tucupita Marcano faces possible lifetime ban for alleged baseball bets, AP source says", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writers Greg Beacham and Will Graves contributed to this report.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/mlb", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, {"uri": "2024-06-378568608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:03:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:03:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:03:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/sports/mlb/padres-tucupita-marcano-mlb-lifetime-ban-betting/3876096/", "title": "MLB bans Padres' Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball", "body": "Marcano is seemingly the first active major leaguer to be banned for gambling in 100 years. New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell was the last in 1924.\n\nAlong with Marcano's lifetime ban, four other players received one-year suspensions for placing unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook. Oakland A's pitcher Michael Kelly, Padres minor league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank were all found to have violated MLB's gambling policies.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a release. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMLB released information on each player's gambling activity and found that Marcano made 25 bets on Pittsburgh Pirates while he was a member of the MLB club in 2023. Marcano made 387 baseball bets and 231 MLB-related bets in all from Oct. 16-23, 2022, and July 12-Nov. 1, 2023. He placed more than $150,000 in bets on baseball and $87,319 on MLB-related wagers.\n\nMLB said that Marcano did not appear in any of the games in which he placed bets and that all of his Pirates-related bets came after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023.\n\nMLB found that Marcano lost all of his Pirates-related parlays and won just 4.3% of his MLB bets overall.\n\nThe league said that there is no evidence to suggest that any of the games that Marcano placed bets on were compromised in any way.\n\nMLB's Rule 21 states that \"any player, umpire, or club or league official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year\" and \"any player, umpire, or club or league official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nMarcano made his MLB debut with the Padres in 2021 and spent the last two seasons with the Pirates. {"uri": "8161423543", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:57:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:57:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:56:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.totalprosports.com/mlb/san-diego-padres-player-banned-by-mlb-for-life-over-astonishing-gambling-accusations/", "title": "San Diego Padres Player Banned By MLB For Life Over Astonishing Gambling Accusations", "body": "Major League Baseball has handed a San Diego Padres infielder a lifetime ban over gambling violations, ending his professional career at just 24 years of age.\n\nOn Tuesday, the league announced punishments for five MLB players for sports betting violations. Those players are Tucupita Marcano of the San Diego Padres (a lifetime ban), Michael Kelly of the Oakland Athletics, Jay Groome (Padres), Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks) and Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez (Philadelphia Phillies).\n\nThe league has permanently banned Marcano after discovering that he placed a whopping 231 MLB bets from Oct. 16, 2022, to Nov. 1, 2023. According to MLB, Marcano wagered over $150,000 on MLB games, including 25 wagers when he was with the Pittsburgh Pirates:\n\n\"Consistent with Marcano's overall baseball betting activity, almost all of Marcano's Pirates bets were on which Club (the Pirates or their opponent) would win the game or whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game. Ultimately, Marcano lost all of his parlays involving the Pirates and only won 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets overall.\n\nThere is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\"\n\nAlso Read: National League Powerhouse Lands Blue Jays Superstar Bo Bichette In Massive Trade Proposal That Would Make Them Overwhelming World Series Favorites\n\nSadly, these five MLB players aren't the only professional athletes to land in hot water for gambling violations. NFL star wide receiver Calvin Ridley was suspended for the 2022 season, taking a year off his prime.\n\nJontay Porter of the NBA's Toronto Raptors was hit with a lifetime ban this year for gambling, and NHL star Shane Pinto of the Ottawa Senators was suspended 41 games for violating the league's rules.\n\nNot to mention that MLB legend Pete Rose isn't in the Hall of Fame strictly because of his gambling scandal.\n\nThe 24-year-old Marcano broke into the majors as a 21-year-old in 2021, appearing in 25 games for the San Diego Padres. He spent the next two seasons with the Pirates, posting a career MLB batting average of .217 with a .589 OPS, five homers and 34 RBI.\n\nThe Padres brought back Marcano on a new deal last year. He never played a game during the 2024 regular season as he recovered from surgery on a torn ACL.\n\nUnfortunately, Marcano's gambling habits have taken away the dream of growing into a full-time MLB starter. It's another strong reminder for young athletes about the dangers of sports betting.", "source": {"uri": "totalprosports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Total Pro Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161429831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:03:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:03:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:01:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/5-mlb-players-have-been-punished-for-violating-gambling-policy/article_cd5446fe-4fdb-56c8-b0b3-ecbb09690632.html", "title": "5 MLB Players Have Been Punished For Violating Gambling Policy", "body": "The MLB started off its Tuesday by suspending five separate players for violating its sports betting policy.\n\nOakland Athletics right-hander Michael Kelly, San Diego Padres left-hander Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies infielder Jose Rodriguez, and Arizona Diamondbacks left-hander Andrew Saalfrank have all been suspended for one year.\n\nPadres infielder Tucupita Marcano, meanwhile, is set to receive a lifetime ban from the MLB. That's because he wagered on Pittsburgh Pirates games when he was a member of the team.\n\nMarcano placed 25 wagers on the Pirates, per the MLB's findings.\n\nHere's more information regarding Marcano's gambling spree:\n\nIn total, Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $378 per bet). Of the over 200 MLB bets Marcano placed over this period, 25 of those bets included Pirates games while he was assigned to the Pirates' Major League Club. Marcano did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets, however, because all of Marcano's Pirates-related bets, and the vast majority of his bets overall, occurred during the period after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park.\n\nMLB commissioner Rob Manfred has made it known the league will continue to enforce a strict policy regarding gambling. Obviously, it's all about maintaining the integrity of the game.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Manfred said.\n\nThese suspensions should serve as warnings to any player even thinking about testing the Specifics of those bets aren't yet known. Four other players are also reportedly under investigation for allegedly betting on games in the minor leagues, too.\n\nThough the investigation into Marcano is still ongoing, a decision on the potential lifetime ban \"could be imminent,\" according to ESPN's Jeff Passan.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played for the Padres this season. {"uri": "2024-06-377658409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:08:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:08:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T16:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-06-03/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano Under Investigation by MLB for Gambling on Baseball, AP Source Says", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writer Greg Beacham contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8161479697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:40:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:40:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:35:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/baseball-padres-marcano-gets-lifetime-mlb-ban-for-betting-on-baseball/2116824/", "title": "Baseball-Padres' Marcano gets lifetime MLB ban for betting on baseball", "body": "\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century.\n\n\"We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nAccording to data obtained from a legal sports betting operator, MLB concluded that Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers from Oct. 16-23, 2022 and from July 12, 2023 through Nov. 1, 2023.\n\nIn total, MLB said the 24-year-old Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets.\n\nMLB also said there is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\n\nMarcano first signed with San Diego as an amateur out of Venezuela in 2016 and made his MLB debut in 2021, appearing in 25 games for the club that season before being traded in July of that year to the Pirates.\n\nMarcano had surgery to repair a torn right anterior cruciate ligament that he sustained last July when he awkwardly stepped on third base during a game.\n\nThe Padres selected Marcano off waivers last November but he had not played for the team since being acquired.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly was also suspended one year for betting on MLB games while he was playing in the minor leagues.\n\nIn addition, MLB said minor league players Jay Groome (Padres pitcher), Jose Rodriguez (Philadelphia Phillies infielder) and Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher) were each banned one year for betting on MLB games.\n\n(Reporting by Frank {"uri": "8160030915", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:30:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:30:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says/QGF4CZIYEBFK5ALHCJBVTLE4RA/", "title": "MLB player Tucupita Marcano faces possible lifetime ban for alleged baseball bets, AP source says", "body": "MLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Sports Writers Greg Beacham and Will Graves contributed to this report.", While The Journal does not have the specifics of those bets, the report states four other players are also under investigation for betting on minor-league contests.\n\nESPN added that the league's investigation into Marcano remains ongoing, though a lifetime ban from the league \"could be imminent.\"\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the Padres told The Wall Street Journal in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigation process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano, a Venezuela native, suffered a right ACL tear last season with the Pirates, ending his campaign after 75 games. He hit .233/.276/.356 with three homers, 12 doubles, two triples and 18 RBI over 202 at-bats.\n\nSHOHEI OHTANI'S FORMER INTERPRETER IPPEI MIZUHARA AGREES TO PLEAD GUILTY TO FEDERAL BANK, TAX FRAUD CHARGES\n\nThe Wall Street Journal reported that Marcano's bets only came after he was injured.\n\nMarcano has not played with the Padres at any level this season, as he continues to recover from his injury.\n\nMarcano's betting allegations come as MLB dealt with Los Angeles Dodgers superstar Shohei Ohtani's now-former interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, reportedly stealing nearly $17 million from the ballplayer to cover gambling losses. Mizuhara pled guilty to federal bank and tax fraud charges following an investigation.\n\nA lifetime ban was also seen in the NBA this past regular season, as Toronto Raptors forward Jontay Porter was found to be purposefully limiting his availability in games for betting purposes, while also betting on games.\n\nEvery professional sports league in the country has similar gambling policies, which prohibit players from placing any bets on their own sport. MLB allows bets to be made on other sports legally.\n\nPer the league's gambling policy, betting on a baseball game involving a team other than the player's own would be a one-year suspension. However, betting on your own team leads to a lifetime ban from the league.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nMarcano started his career with the Padres, making his debut in 2021 when he slashed .182/.280/.205 over 25 games. {"uri": "8161329974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:56:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:56:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:54:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/mlb/news/tucupita-marcano-lifetime-suspension-padres-gambling/311aa5a5916e4faaea57607b", "title": "Tucupita Marcano lifetime MLB ban, explained: Why Padres infielder was suspended over gambling violation", "body": "The rise in sports betting, promoted by virtually all professional sports leagues, has created an awkward and often confusing dynamic for players. MLB is making sure there is no confusion with its decision to ban Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for life over gambling violations.\n\nAn investigation into Marcano was first reported by the Wall Street Journal on Monday, with the revelation that four other players are also under investigation by the league. MLB announced Marcano's ban on Tuesday, June 4.\n\nThe NBA faced a similar situation in April when Raptors forward Jontay Porter was permanently banned from the league after it was found that he bet against himself a month earlier.\n\nWhile each league might be fortunate that the subjects of the ban were largely low-profile talents, both situations are a reminder of the potential crisis professional sports would face if larger violations came to light.\n\nHere's a look at why Marcano was banned for life, plus a dive into his background.\n\nMORE: Which players benefit most from MLB-Negro Leagues stats integration?\n\nMarcano was under investigation for betting on Pirates games while on the injured list with the Pirates in 2023. His bets were flagged by a sportsbook and reported to MLB, according to ESPN.\n\nWhile that means Marcano wasn't betting in games he could directly impact, as he was recovering from a torn ACL at the time, betting on baseball is strictly against MLB rules for players and triggered a lifetime ban.\n\nFive players, including Marcano, are the subject of MLB's investigation into gambling violations, the Wall Street Journal reported. A's Michael Kelly, Padres' Jay Groome, Phillies Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Diamondbacks' Andrew Saalfrank each face a one-year ban.\n\nMarcano's ban marks the second major gambling scandal of the year for MLB, though the first wasn't centered on a player. Shohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Dodgers in March after the revelation that he bet on sports with an illegal bookmaker and stole millions from Ohtani to cover his gambling debts. Mizuhara faced federal charges and agreed to a plea deal in May, though the deal hasn't yet been finalized.\n\nNo evidence connects Ohtani to the bookmaker, but Braves minor-leaguer and former Angels infielder David Fletcher is reportedly under investigation for placing bets with the same bookmaker.\n\nMarcano was claimed by the Padres this past offseason after spending two seasons in Pittsburgh. Here's a closer look at his career.\n\nMarcano made his MLB debut with the Padres at only 21 in 2021. He was traded to the Pirates in a midseason deal that sent Adam Frazier to San Diego.\n\nMarcano found an opportunity for playing time in Pittsburgh, appearing in 49 games in 2022 but batting just .206 with two home runs and a .562 OPS. Marcano hit .233 with a .633 OPS across 75 games in 2023 before suffering a torn ACL.\n\nIt was at that point that Marcano reportedly bet on baseball, doing so while he was out on the injured list with the Pirates.\n\nMarcano was claimed by the Padres on Nov. 2 and remained on the major-league IL while continuing his recovery from a torn ACL before the lifetime ban.\n\nMORE: How Luis Gil became surprise Cy Young candidate\n\nMarcano's MLB future was uncertain before his gambling violations came to light, as he struggled through parts of three seasons to start his career.\n\nWhile he's still just 24 and was capable of playing both middle infield positions as well as the outfield, Marcano had just a .589 OPS across 149 games and didn't show signs of hitting for much power.", "source": {"uri": "8161512556", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:02:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:02:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:00:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb-hits-tucupita-marcano-lifetime-165525147.html", "title": "MLB hits Tucupita Marcano with lifetime ban for betting on baseball games", "body": "Major League Baseball banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on the sport, officials said Tuesday, making him the first active player hit with such a penalty in more than a century.\n\nThe 24-year-old Venezuelan broke into MLB in 2021 with the Padres before he was traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates, released and picked up by the Friars again this past off season.\n\nHe hadn't appeared in a game this season, recovering from a knee injury.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano bet through a legal sports book with wagers coming in two spans of time -- in 2022, from Oct. 16 through Oct. 23, and again in 2023 from July 12 through Nov. 1, according to MLB.\n\nHe made a total of 387 bets on both domestic and international baseball, with 231 of those wagers on MLB action, the league said. The bets were for a total of more than $150,000 with $87,319 of that action on MLB games, the league added.\n\nAnd of those MLB bets, 25 involved Pirates games while Marcano was with the Bucs, though he did not appear in any of those contests.\n\nIn fact, a \"vast majority\" of Marcano's wagers \"occurred during the period after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023 and was receiving medical treatment,\" MLB said.\n\nThe last active player kicked out baseball for gambling was New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924.\n\nPete Rose, MLB's career leader in base hits, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after he was found to have wagered on baseball games while managing the Cincinnati Reds.\n\nMLB on Tuesday also announced one-year suspensions for four other players it found in violation of league gambling prohibitions.\n\nIn the case of all five players, MLB said there's \"no evidence to suggest\" that \"any outcomes in the baseball games\" wagered upon \"were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\"\n\nA message for Rimas Sports, the agency that represents Marcano, was not immediately returned to NBC News on Tuesday, seeking comment on behalf of the player.\n\nA rep for the Major League Baseball Players Association also could not be immediately reached for comment on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8161329716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:54:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:54:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:54:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-gambling-scandal-explained-padres-tucupita-marcano-gets-lifetime-ban-for-baseball-bets-others-punished/", "title": "MLB gambling scandal explained: Padres' Tucupita Marcano gets lifetime ban for baseball bets, others punished - CBSSports.com", "body": "Four other players have been suspended for one year each for betting on MLB games, but not their own team Getty Images\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been permanently banned from Major League Baseball after violating the league's gambling policy, MLB announced on Tuesday. Marcano's ban was accompanied by one-year suspensions for four other players: Oakland Athletics reliever Michael Kelly and minor-league players Jay Groome (Padres pitcher), Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez (Philadelphia Phillies infielder) and Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher).\n\nMLB received data from a legal sports betting operator concerning baseball gambling activity from accounts that belonged to the above players, the league announced. Under MLB's rules, personnel are allowed to partake in sports gambling provided that it is legal in their jurisdiction and that they do not bet on diamond sports -- that is, baseball or softball. Each player violated the second part of that.\n\nNone of the players are appealing their suspension.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people. Since the Supreme Court decision opened the door to legalized sports betting, we have worked with licensed sports betting operators and other third parties to put ourselves in a better position from an integrity perspective through the transparency that a regulated sports betting system can provide. MLB will continue to invest heavily in integrity monitoring, educational programming and awareness initiatives with the goal of ensuring strict adherence to this fundamental rule of our game.\"\n\nHere's what you need to know about Marcano, the other players, and MLB's history of gambling penalties.\n\nMarcano banned for life\n\nMarcano, 24, was signed by the Padres as an amateur free agent out of Venezuela in 2016. He was traded to the Pirates in 2021 with Jack Suwinski for Adam Frazier and last November went back to the Padres on waivers. He hasn't played a game since last July after tearing his ACL.\n\nMLB's investigation found that Marcano didn't just bet on baseball frequently -- he's claimed to have gambled more than $150,000 across nearly 400 baseball bets, including on MLB and international contests -- but that he even bet on his own team, then the Pirates. \"[Almost] all of Marcano's Pirates bets were on which club (the Pirates or their opponent) would win the game or whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game,\" MLB said in a press release.\n\nIt's notable that Marcano did not appear in any of the games that he bet on because of his injury. He also denied having inside information that influenced his bets. MLB estimates that he won just 4.3% of his MLB-related gambles.\n\nOther players didn't bet on own games\n\nAs for the other players -- Kelly, Groome, Rodr\u00edguez, and Saalfrank -- they all placed bets on MLB games that they were not part of themselves. They did, however, bet on games played by their organization's major-league team while they were in the minors. None of them bet on baseball with the frequency that Marcano, either.\n\nHere's a complete breakdown of the data MLB provided on the four players' bets:\n\nPlayerMLB betsAverage $ per betNet\n\nKelly\n\n10\n\n$9.92\n\n$28.30\n\nGroome\n\n32\n\n$15.12\n\n-$433.54\n\nRodr\u00edguez\n\n28\n\n$25.86\n\nN/A\n\nSaalfrank\n\n28\n\n$15.86\n\n-$272.64\n\nKelly, 31, is the most notable of the bunch given that he was a member of the Athletics' active roster. In 28 games this season, he had amassed a 2.59 ERA (151 ERA+) and a 2.20 strikeout-to-walk ratio. Kelly, then with the Astros' Triple-A team, placed 10 bets on nine MLB games (including three Houston games) between Oct. 5, 2021 through Oct. 17, 2021. In total, he bet $99.22 and won five of the bets, putting him at a net win of $28.30.\n\nGroome, assigned to the Red Sox's High-A team, made 32 bets on MLB games between July 22, 2020 through July 24, 2021, including 24 on Boston games. He bet $453.74 and lost $433.54. He received payouts on just two bets.\n\nRodr\u00edguez, who was playing for the White Sox's Double-A team, made 31 baseball bets on Sept. 30, 2021, and from June 5, 2022 through July 30, 2022, including on several college baseball games. In total, he bet $749.09 on baseball, $724.09 of which went to MLB-related bets.\n\nSaalfrank, who was on the injured list in the Diamondbacks' Low-A affiliate, made 28 MLB-related bets and one on college baseball games between Sept. 9, 2021 and Oct. 29, 2021 and on March 9, 2022. He bet $445.87 on baseball, with $444.07 of that on MLB-related bets. He had a net loss of $272.64 on MLB bets, losing all but five of his bets. He also lost his $1.80 college bet. Saalfrank pitched in two games in the majors for the Diamondbacks this year and in the 2023 playoffs for Arizona, including three games in the World Series.\n\nMLB's gambling policy\n\nAs noted in the introduction, MLB allows personnel to gamble on sports provided that it's legal in their territory and that it's on non-diamond sports. The individuals suspended on Tuesday were found to have violated Rule 21, which features two notable points.\n\nThe first, violated by the non-Marcano players, states: \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year.\"\n\nThe other, violated specifically by Marcano, states: \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nOther MLB gambling scandals\n\nEarlier this season, Ippei Mizuhara -- Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter -- was charged with stealing more than $16 million from Ohtani to pay off gambling debts to an illegal bookie. He faces a maximum of 33 years in prison. Braves minor-leaguer David Fletcher is also being investigated by MLB for placing bets with the same illegal bookmaker that Mizuhara used. Neither Mizuhara nor Fletcher is alleged to have gambled on baseball, but betting on any sport through illegal channels is also forbidden by MLB. Earlier this year, CBS Sports delved into more detail on other historical baseball gambling scandals.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, "authors": The MLB Players Association declined to comment.\n\nThe Padres issued a statement Monday saying the team is \"aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nThe Pirates are also \"aware of the matter that's under investigation,\" Senior Vice President of Communications Brian Warecki said in a statement, \"and are fully cooperating.\"\n\n\"We will refrain from further comment at this time,\" Warecki said.\n\nFour other players face possible MLB discipline for gambling on baseball games while in the minor leagues, the Journal reported, citing unnamed sources.\n\nPer MLB rules, a player found guilty of betting on baseball games involving teams other than their own are subject to a one-year suspension. A player gambling on their own team's games will receive a lifetime ban.\n\nMarcano has a career batting average of .217 in 149 big league games, but has yet to feature for the Padres this season.",
