{"uri": "2024-06-378557431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:54:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:54:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:51:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/2024/06/04/tucupita-marcano-mlb-gambling-lifetiime-ban-suspension/73969941007/", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life after gambling probe; 4 other players get one-year suspensions", "body": "Orioles' legend Cal Ripken Jr. offers a unique perspective on the issues surrounding youth sports today at the Project Play Summit at Aspen Institute.\n\nMajor League Baseball on Tuesday banned infielder Tucupita Marcano for life after he placed bets on games involving his team and issued one-year bans to four other players who bet on MLB games, in a pivotal moment for the league's simultaneous embrace and policing of legalized sports betting.\n\nMarcano, 24, bet more than $150,000 on baseball in two significant periods between October 2022 and November 2023, and placed 25 bets on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates after he suffered a season-ending knee injury in a July 2023 game.\n\nMarcano, a career .217 hitter in 149 career games, was placed on waivers by the Pirates in November and claimed by the San Diego Padres. He has not appeared in a Padres game this season as he recovers from knee surgery.\n\nFour more players, including Andrew Saalfrank, a member of the National League pennant-winning Arizona Diamondbacks, received one-year bans for betting on MLB games, occurring in a period spanning July 2020 and July 2022. Jay Groome, a former top Red Sox prospect now in the Padres system, placed 24 of his 32 bets on the Red Sox while he was in their minor league system.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, who has appeared in 46 major league games for Cleveland, Philadelphia and the A's since 2022, placed 10 bets on MLB games in October 2021 when he was a member of the Astros organization.\n\nPhillies minor league infielder Jose Rodriguez placed three bets on college baseball games and 28 bets on MLB games on Sept. 30, 2021 and between June 5 and June 30, 2022, when he was in the White Sox organization.\n\nAnd Saalfrank, who did not give up an earned run in 10 appearances for the Diamondbacks in 2023, placed 28 bets on MLB games and one college baseball parlay in September and October 2021, and on March 9, 2022.\n\nBut the most startling finding by MLB's Department of Investigations - working in collaboration with MLB's betting partners, the league said - involved Marcano.\n\nHe bet $87,319 on MLB games, averaging $378 per bet, largely parlays or multi-sport parlays in which an MLB game was a leg of the bet. His longest period of betting occurred between July 12 and Nov. 1, 2023; he suffered his season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023.\n\nMLB reports that Marcano lost all of his bets involving the Pirates, and lost 95.7% of his bets involving MLB games.\n\n\"There is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way,\" MLB said in its statement.\n\nMLB's permanently ineligible list dates to the 19 century, when players were banned for game-fixing and other improprieties. Most notably, eight players from the Chicago White Sox were banned in 1921 after MLB ruled they conspired to fix the 1919 World Series.\n\nAnd all-time hits leader Pete Rose remains banned for life after he gambled on Cincinnati Reds games that he managed.\n\nYet after the widespread acceptance of legalized sports gambling following a 2018 Supreme Court decision - it's now legal in 38 states and the District of Columbia - the calculus has significantly changed. It leaves MLB in a position to welcome the revenue of online sports books - it has official partnerships with FanDuel, DraftKings and MGM - while aiming to maintain the integrity of its games.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \" The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\n\n\"Since the Supreme Court decision opened the door to legalized sports betting, we have worked with licensed sports betting operators and other third parties to put ourselves in a better position from an integrity perspective through the transparency that a regulated sports betting system can provide. MLB will continue to invest heavily in integrity monitoring, educational programming and awareness initiatives with the goal of ensuring strict adherence to this fundamental rule of our game.\"", {"uri": "2024-06-377653325", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:01:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:01:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:49:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/sports/2024/06/03/tucupita-marcano-padres-betting-pirates-mlb/73963821007/", "title": "Padres infielder\\u00a0Tucupita Marcano is reportedly facing a lifetime ban for betting on his own team: Everything we know", "body": "Major League Baseball can't seem to escape the shadow of sports betting scandal, and a new one may be rocking the league soon, pending the results of a new investigation.\n\nAccording to the Wall Street Journal, MLB is investigating San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for violating the league's gambling policy while he was a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates in 2023.\n\nHere's everything we know about this new development:\n\nWho is Tucupita Marcano\n\nThis was the first question I had, so I'm sure many of you are wondering the same thing, as Marcano is not a household name.\n\nMarcano is a 24-year-old Venezuelan who has played 149 games in the majors since 2021, including a career-high 75 games for the Pirates last season. After starting his career with the Padres in 2021, he played in Pittsburgh the last two years before returning to San Diego on a waiver claim last November.\n\nHe hasn't played a game since tearing his ACL with the Pirates last July, but he was hitting .233 with three HR, 18 RBI and five stolen bases before the injury.\n\nWhat did he do?\n\nMarcano is being investigated for betting on games involving the Pirates while he was on the injured list for the team, WSJ's Jared Diamond and Lindsey Adler have reported.\n\nThough he declined to comment, as well as MLB and the MLBPA, the Padres said they were aware of an active investigation.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nWhat will the punishment be?\n\nIf Marcano did bet on games involving his own team, the punishment could be a lifetime ban from baseball.\n\nWSJ is reporting the punishment hasn't been finalized, pending negotiations between the league and players association. However, MLB only allows for players to bet on sports other than baseball. Players who bet on MLB games not involving than their own teams face a one-year ban, and players who bet on games involving their teams face a lifetime suspension.\n\nMarcano isn't alone\n\nFour other players also face potential discipline for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues, according to the WSJ. Though the names of those players weren't reported.\n\nThis news comes after ESPN reported in May that former Angles infielder and current Braves minor leaguer David Fletcher bet on sports with the same illegal bookmaker as Shohei Ohtani's ex-interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara. {"uri": "8161350194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:08:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:08:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:07:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5539792/2024/06/04/tucupita-marcano-permanent-ban-mlb-sports-betting/", "title": "MLB permanently bans Padres' Marcano for betting", "body": "MLB's Department of Investigations found Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets, through a legal sportsbook in 2022 and 2023, the league said. He bet more than $150,000 on baseball, including $87,319 on MLB-related bets, the league said. Additionally, Marcano placed 25 bets on Pirates games last season while he was on the team. However, all of these wagers occurred after he suffered a season-ending knee injury in July 2023.\n\nMarcano, 24, is believed to be the first major leaguer to receive a permanent ban for gambling on baseball since MLB career hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 for betting on games as a Cincinnati Reds player and manager from 1985 to 1987.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century.\"\n\nMLB also suspended four other players for one year -- Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, Padres minor-league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor-league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodriguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor-league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank -- for violating MLB's betting policies. The Department of Investigations found all four players placed MLB-related bets while in the minors.\n\nMLB said a legal sports betting operator informed the league in March that it had \"identified past baseball betting activity\" from accounts connected to multiple players. None of the evidence suggested the games the players placed bets on were compromised, the league said.\n\nThe punishments were issued in accordance with Major League Rule 21, which states, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year.\"\n\nIn Marcano's case, the rule states, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nThe MLB Players' Association declined to comment.\n\n\"The A's were disappointed to learn of the matter involving Michael Kelly,\" the A's said in a statement Tuesday. \"While we cannot comment on the details, this violation occurred prior to Michael joining the A's organization and we fully support MLB's sports betting policy and the need to adhere to all provisions of Rule 21.\"\n\nMarcano hadn't played since July 24, 2023, due to a torn right ACL. He appeared in 149 games from 2021 to 2023 with the Padres and Pirates.\n\nThis story will be updated.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "8161383520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:39:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:39:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:29:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://kion546.com/sports/cnn-sports/2024/06/04/san-diego-padres-player-tucupita-marcano-banned-for-life-by-mlb-after-betting-on-games/", "title": "San Diego Padres player Tucupita Marcano banned for life by MLB after betting on games - KION546", "body": "As well as announcing Marcano's punishment, the MLB also on Tuesday banned four other baseball players for a year apiece for violating betting rules.\n\nAccording to an MLB investigation, Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related ones, over two periods in 2022 and 2023 while he was a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates and while he was on the injured list. He gambled more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets.\n\nThe MLB investigation found that 25 of those bets included Pirates games while Marcano was assigned to the Major League club.\n\nThe MLB probe found that \"almost all of Marcano's Pirates bets were on which club (the Pirates or their opponent) would win the game or whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game.\"\n\nThe MLB investigation said that \"there is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\"\n\nThe four other players were banned for one year for betting on baseball games while in the minor leagues.\n\nThose players are Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, Padres minor league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank.\n\nThe MLB said that none of the players are appealing their discipline.\n\nAccording to MLB rules, a player found guilty of betting on baseball games involving teams other than their own are subject to a one-year suspension. A player gambling on their own team's games will receive a lifetime ban.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\n\n\"Since the Supreme Court decision opened the door to legalized sports betting, we have worked with licensed sports betting operators and other third parties to put ourselves in a better position from an integrity perspective through the transparency that a regulated sports betting system can provide,\" added Manfred.\n\n\"MLB will continue to invest heavily in integrity monitoring, educational programming and awareness initiatives with the goal of ensuring strict adherence to this fundamental rule of our game.\"\n\nOakland pitcher Kelly was found to have placed 10 bets involving nine MLB games for a total of $99.22. He did not appear in any of the games on which he bet, and he did not make any bets involving his assigned team.\n\nThe A's said in a statement they were \"disappointed to learn\" about Kelly's betting infringements.\n\n\"While we cannot comment on the details, this violation occurred prior to Michael joining the A's organization and we fully support MLB's sports betting policy and the need to adhere to all provisions of Rule 21,\" the A's said in a statement.\n\n\"We will continue to educate all members of our organization regarding their obligations under the policy.\"\n\nThis story has been updated with additional information.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8161350244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:08:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:08:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:07:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/mlb/2024/6/4/24171221/tucupita-marcanos-lifetime-ban-mlb-gambling-scandal-players-explained", "title": "Tucupita Marcano's lifetime ban in MLB gambling scandal, explained", "body": "Tucupita Marcano joined the San Diego Padres as an international free agent in 2016 with dreams of playing in the major leagues. He finally reached the big leagues in 2021 with the Padres, recording his first MLB hit in a game against the San Francisco Giants that April. He also hit his first MLB home run that season in a game for the Pittsburgh Pirates, as he was traded to the NL Central team ahead of the trade deadline that year.\n\nBut any dreams of further MLB success are now over.\n\nMarcano was one of five players suspended by the league on Tuesday for betting on baseball. Along with Marcano, Michael Kelly of the Oakland A's was the other MLB player hit with disciplinary action by the league. Three Minor League players -- Jay Groome, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez, and Andrew Saalfrank -- were also disciplined.\n\nWhile the other four players were all given one-year suspensions, Marcano has been banned from the game for life.\n\nHere is why.\n\nAccording to the league, in March of 2024 MLB \"... learned from a legal sports betting operator that it had identified past baseball betting activity from accounts connected to multiple Major and Minor League players.\" This information touched off a lengthy investigation by the league that \" ... included interviews, thorough review of the available information in each matter, and significant cooperation from MLB's legal sportsbook partners.\"\n\nOver the course of their investigation, the league found that:\n\n\"None of these players played in any game on which they placed a bet. Further, all of the players denied that they had any inside information relevant to the bets or that any of the baseball games they bet on were compromised or manipulated, and the betting data does not suggest that any outcomes in the baseball games on which they placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way. None of the players are appealing their discipline.\"\n\nHowever Rule 21(d), which governs sports betting, reads as follows:\n\n(1) Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year.\n\n(2) Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\n\nRegarding Marcano, the investigation found that he placed a staggering number of bets on MLB games, including during a period of time he was rehabbing for a knee injury with the Pirates.\n\nAccording to the league's investigation, \"[b]etting data shows that from October 16, 2022 through October 23, 2022, and from July 12, 2023 through November 1, 2023, Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets among other bets on international baseball games through a legal sportsbook. Marcano's MLB bets were generally parlays, which would sometimes include multiple MLB-related legs, and they would sometimes include MLB-related legs and non-MLB legs.\"\n\nThe league's investigation uncovered that the infielder \" ... bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $378 per bet). Of the over 200 MLB bets Marcano placed over this period, 25 of those bets included Pirates games while he was assigned to the Pirates' Major League Club. Marcano did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets, however, because all of Marcano's Pirates-related bets, and the vast majority of his bets overall, occurred during the period after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park.\"\n\nThere is no evidence to suggest that Marcano \"compromised, influenced, or manipulated\" games in any way.\n\nOf those bets he made, Marcano \"only won 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets overall,\" and lost every parlay bet he made involving the Pirates.\n\nGiven that some of those bets were made while Marcano was undergoing treatment from the Pirates at PNC Park for his knee injury, Marcano's activity fell under Rule 21(d)(2) of the MLB Rules, which outlines that players cannot place bets on games involving their own team.\n\nAs such, his conduct necessitated a permanent ban from major league baseball.\n\nThe other four players -- Kelly, Groome, Rodr\u00edguez, Saalfrank -- were all found to have bet on MLB games, but according to the league's investigation none of their bets involved their own team. For example, Saalfrank \"... placed 29 baseball bets, including 28 MLB-related bets and one parlay bet on college baseball games, while he was on a Minor League contract with the Diamondbacks. Saalfrank placed all of his MLB-related bets, including four bets involving the Diamondbacks' Major League team, while he was assigned to and on the Injured List of the Diamondbacks' Low-A affiliate.\"\n\nThe investigation found that Saalfrank \" ... bet $445.87 on baseball, with $444.07 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $15.86 per bet) and with a net loss of $272.64 on MLB bets.\"\n\nHe won only five of his 28 MLB bets, and lost the single college bet, where he wagered $1.80.\n\nIn the announcement from the league Tuesday, MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred issued this statement:\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans. The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\n\n\"Since the Supreme Court decision opened the door to legalized sports betting, we have worked with licensed sports betting operators and other third parties to put ourselves in a better position from an integrity perspective through the transparency that a regulated sports betting system can provide. MLB will continue to invest heavily in integrity monitoring, educational programming and awareness initiatives with the goal of ensuring strict adherence to this fundamental rule of our game.\"", {"uri": "8161333642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:57:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:57:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:57:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/sports/mlb/padres-tucupita-marcano-mlb-lifetime-ban-betting/3632223/", "title": "MLB bans Padres' Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball", "body": "Marcano is seemingly the first active major leaguer to be banned for gambling in 100 years. New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell was the last in 1924.\n\nAlong with Marcano's lifetime ban, four other players received one-year suspensions for placing unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook. Oakland A's pitcher Michael Kelly, Padres minor league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank were all found to have violated MLB's gambling policies.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a release. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMLB released information on each player's gambling activity and found that Marcano made 25 bets on Pittsburgh Pirates while he was a member of the MLB club in 2023. Marcano made 387 baseball bets and 231 MLB-related bets in all from Oct. 16-23, 2022, and July 12-Nov. 1, 2023. He placed more than $150,000 in bets on baseball and $87,319 on MLB-related wagers.\n\nMLB said that Marcano did not appear in any of the games in which he placed bets and that all of his Pirates-related bets came after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023.\n\nMLB found that Marcano lost all of his Pirates-related parlays and won just 4.3% of his MLB bets overall.\n\nThe league said that there is no evidence to suggest that any of the games that Marcano placed bets on were compromised in any way.", "source": {"uri": "nbcwashington.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8160273139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "02:26:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T02:26:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T02:24:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/mlb/san-diego-padres/2024/06/04/665e69e022601d06638b4645.html", "title": "The Shohei Ohtani effect: Another star MLB player facing lifetime ban for betting on his team", "body": "Shohei Ohtani former Angels teammate investigated for betting with sportsbook that accepted bets from his interpreter\n\nThe San Diego Padres are one of the contenders to reach the playoffs and fight for a World Series ring, first trying to get past the Los Angeles Dodgers and the rest of the talented teams in the National League like the Philadelphia Phillies, Atlanta Braves and Milwaukee Brewers.\n\nThey need all the help they can get even with a very good roster and one of those players that could have helped them towards the end of the season was Venezuelan infielder Tucupita Marcano, a player spends some time with the team in the past and resign with San Diego after a stint in Pittsburgh with the Pirates. Now it looks like he might play baseball at all.\n\nMarcano is being investigated by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and is facing a lifetime suspension. MLB is investigating allegations that Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while he was on the team's injured list last season.\n\nThe 24-year-old player has not played since suffering a torn cruciate ligament in his knee on July 24. He was taken by the Padres after being placed on the transfer list on November 2 and went on the 10-day disabled list on March 19.\n\nIn a year were Shohei Ohtani's agent was involved in a betting scandal, the matter is a delicate one for the league and the fans. Credibility has been an issue for the Dodgers' player and now a second situation of similar sorts is catastrophic for MLB.\n\nThe San Diego Padres have spoken about the matter in a statement. \"We are aware that there is an ongoing investigation by Major League Baseball into a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and was not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said. \"We will not be issuing any further comment until the investigation process is complete.\"\n\nMLB Rule 21, which appears posted in every clubhouse, states that betting on a baseball game in which a player, umpire, league employee or team personnel has no participation will result in a one-year suspension. However, betting on a game in which a person is somehow involved can result in a lifetime ban.\n\nPete Rose, the major league's all-time hits leader, accepted a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation determined he bet on Cincinnati Reds games when he was the team's manager.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and posted a .217 batting average with five home runs, {"uri": "8160033421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:32:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:32:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:31:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/sports/national/mlb-player-tucupita-marcano-faces-possible-lifetime-ban-for-alleged-baseball-bets-ap-source-says/article_cfe606a7-b2eb-5284-9933-60e9a4a5f14c.html", "title": "MLB player Tucupita Marcano faces possible lifetime ban for alleged baseball bets, AP source says", "body": "By RONALD BLUM - AP Baseball Writer\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano could be the second pro athlete banned for life over sports betting this year after the NBA punished Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter in April following a league probe that found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and wagered on games.\n\nIt's believed that no active MLB player has been banned for betting on baseball since 1924. Pete Rose was retired when he agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989.\n\nPeople are also reading... Buffalo Diocese plans to cut number of parishes by a third in latest restructuring Alan Pergament: Kate Welshofer has a new gig at the National Comedy Center Diocese cancels concert that includes gay chorus, cites values 'inconsistent with Catholic teaching' Bills observations: Damar Hamlin shines, secondary clings to WRs downfield 6-year-old girl dies after being hit by van in Town of Tonawanda Bills Mailbag: Why Tyler Bass is a cause for concern entering 2024 season At St. Margaret's, some congregants worry about its fate Western New York towns that host prisons wait to see if their facilities will close Erie County real estate transactions How the Sabres scouted, drafted QMJHL top defenseman Vsevelod Komarov La'el Collins healthy, eager to show Bills his top tackle form Explainer: Fabricators essential in producing local steel for Bills stadium project Mats Lindgren among trio of prospects Sabres opt to not sign before deadline Buffalo hires lawyer convicted of filing false documents with IRS to city job Ryan O'Halloran: New number, new position coach, new outlook for Bills cornerback Kaiir Elam\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players were under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating,\" Pirates senior vice president of communications Brian Warecki said in a statement. \"We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nRose, baseball's career hits leader, agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nU.S. sports leagues have increased monitoring over gambling since the U.S. Supreme Court in May 2018 struck down a federal law that had barred betting on football, basketball, baseball and other sports in most states. Sports books have opened at stadiums across the country across the major U.S. pro sports.\n\nShohei Ohtani's interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers after the season opener on March 21 when a federal gambling investigation became public. Mizuhara agreed to plead guilty to bank and tax fraud in a sports betting case in which prosecutors allege he stole nearly $17 million from the two-time AL MVP to pay off debts.\n\nBaseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said last month that the sport's department of investigations deferred to the government probe. He noted that MLB has superior methods of monitoring potentially illicit bets with legal sports books than with illegal bookmakers. It is not clear how Marcano might have made his alleged bets.\n\nMLB's top concern with legal sports betting is on action besides the score or outcome, known as prop bets. For instance, wagers that a certain player would steal at least one base in a given game.\n\n\"There are certain kinds of prop bets that are of concern to us and continue to be of concern to us,\" Manfred said. \"Obviously, the potential for something happening in the game that nobody notices is much higher with a lot of kinds of prop bets and you could see where a player would be more tempted to -- all you need to do is miss three free throws; it doesn't necessarily change the outcome of your game. Your team may pick you up and life moves on. It's just easier to have a problem on a prop bet. I think it's just human nature. So, yeah, we remain concerned about them and have lobbied for certain types of prop bets not to be allowable.\"\n\nAP Sports Writers Greg Beacham and Will Graves contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/mlb\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8160067200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "22:09:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T22:09:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T22:08:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://sportsnaut.com/tucupita-marcano-mlb-lifetime-ban/", "title": "MLB player Tucupita Marcano reportedly facing lifetime ban for allegedly betting on games", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is currently recovering from a torn ACL he suffered a season ago. That injury might now be the last time Marcano takes to a MLB field.\n\nAccording to multiple media reports, the 24-year-old infielder is facing a potential lifetime ban by Major League Baseball for betting on games.\n\nESPN's Jeff Passan reports that Marcano allegedly bet on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was a member of that team a season ago.\n\n\"Marcano, 24, has yet to be formally penalized, but MLB Rule 21 explicitly states that a player who bets on games involving his own team is subject to a lifetime ban. Marcano tore an ACL last year and was on the injured list when he allegedly placed the bets, which were flagged by a sportsbook and reported to the league, according to sources.\"\n\nThe Wall Street Journal also reports that four minor league baseball players are facing similar bans for allegedly betting on games.\n\nThis comes with MLB also investigating former Los Angeles Angels player David Fletcher for betting on sports. That came to light amid a separate investigation into Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter Ippei Mizuhara.\n\nThis is becoming a real issue around the sports world. It was earlier in the year that the NBA handed down a lifetime ban to former Toronto Raptors players Jontay Porter for disclosing confidential information to bettors.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8161348876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:07:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:07:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:06:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_6c423447-60be-5203-b2e4-a57fbb6e6376.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nMasyn Winn's hit streak halts with strategic decision Cardinals manager 'didn't want to make' Girl found dead in Jefferson County was aspiring softball pitcher, 'loved everybody' Battlehawks employ UFL rulebook to earn win, capture home field for playoffs Sultan: How much longer will the cicadas be here? Edwardsville mother wanted teen son arrested to save his life Urban Chestnut owes more than $400K from unpaid loans, lawsuits claim Messenger: Ballwin chief misused criminal database and ran hundreds of names, report says Pevely mom tried to 'sacrifice' toddler before drowning him in Jefferson County, charges say 17 shot, 3 killed in weekend of mayhem in St. Louis Back in Memphis, Cardinals outfielder Jordan Walker feels he's 'swinging it a little bit better' Pet food maker Purina too 'woke' for Missouri Republican. So she 'fires' her employer. Man charged with threatening school graduation after son killed in south St. Louis County Cardinals Zack Thompson delivers hitless start, Jordan Walker doubles twice: Minor League Report Cafes bring new late-night culture to West County, St. Charles From mapping cicadas to measuring sound, researchers track the brood around St. Louis\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-377663364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:16:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:16:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:07:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/2024/06/03/mlb-investigating-padres-player-for-betting-on-his-teams-games/73963565007/", "title": "MLB investigating Padres' Tucupita Marcano for gambling on games in 2023", "body": "Major League Baseball's biggest nightmare since sports gambling's widespread legalization has come to fruition: An active player faces a suspension and potential lifetime ban for betting on baseball.\n\nTucupita Marcano, a utility player on the San Diego Padres' injured list, is under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, according to the Wall Street Journal. Marcano, a 24-year-old native of Venezuela, reportedly placed the bets in 2023, when he was a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates.\n\nThe Pirates, in a statement to USA TODAY Sports, said they are \"fully cooperating\" with the MLB probe.\n\nMarcano suffered a torn ACL in his right knee in July 2023 and has been on the injured list since. The Padres, who originally signed him out of Venezuela in 2016, claimed him off waivers from Pittsburgh in November.\n\nUnder MLB's gambling policy, players face a one-year ban for betting on a major league game and a lifetime ban if they placed bets on games involving their own team. The Journal reported that he placed bets on games involving the Pirates.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the Padres said in a statement released to news outlets, including USA TODAY Sports. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nSaid the Pirates in a statement: \"We are aware of the matter that's under investigation and are fully cooperating. We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nMLB's relationship with illegal gambling - dating to the 1919 World Series infamously thrown by the Chicago White Sox, through the shame of all-time hits leader Pete Rose earning a lifetime ban for betting on games he managed for the Cincinnati Reds - has given way to an uneasy embrace, since the 2018 Supreme Court decision that left legalized gambling up to the states.\n\nThe league - and virtually every team - has signed multiple official agreements with online and physical casinos, while maintaining a ban on baseball betting for its players.\n\n\"DO NOT BET ON BASEBALL,\" reads a placard in major league clubhouses, with a QR code sending them to a web site that spells out baseball's gambling policy. It states that players may not bet on baseball at any level, nor can they ask others to place bets on their behalf.\n\nYet the Marcano investigation is the league's second high-profile scandal just two months into the season. Ippei Mizuhara, the longtime interpreter for dual-threat superstar Shohei Ohtani, was fired by the Los Angeles Dodgers and has reached a plea agreement with federal prosecutors after he allegedly stole nearly $17 million from Ohtani.\n\nMizuhara has said he has an online account with DraftKings and assumed the bets with the alleged bookmaker were legal.\n\nThat federal probe also sparked an investigation into longtime major league infielder David Fletcher, who introduced Mizuhara to the alleged bookmaker and, ESPN reported, placed bets on sports other than baseball with the bookie. Fletcher is currently with the Atlanta Braves' Class AAA team.\n\nSince the 2018 Supreme Court decision, 38 states, including Pennsylvania, and the District of Columbia have legalized sports gambling. MLB has official partnerships with online casinos FanDuel, DraftKings and MGM.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut for the Padres in 2021 and has played in 149 career games, with a .217 average, five home runs and a .589 OPS. He was traded along with outfielder Jack Suwinski to Pittsburgh in July 2021 in exchange for infielder Adam Frazier.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucupita_Marcano", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tucupita Marcano"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego_Padres", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "San Diego Padres"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates", "type": "wiki", "score": Notable offenders most famously include the all-time hits leader Pete Rose.\n\nBetween Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, Marcano was found to have bet a total of $150,000, including $87,319 on MLB. The averaged amount of money placed on each bet included $378. Then the total amount of MLB bets were 231 and of those 25 were bets on Pirates games.\n\nIf you are curious how much Marcano won, he had a winning percentage of 4.3%. That is to say, unlike Rose, Marcano reportedly did not appear in any games that he bet on, which is because his season ended early when he underwent surgery.\n\nNow for the specifics of the regulations involving Rule 21, a player, or coach or umpire, is not allowed to bet on baseball, but if they do bet on a team they are not affiliated with, then it is only a one-year suspension. Then on the other hand, if a player bets on a game in which they are subject to participate in, it is indeed a lifetime ban.\n\nThere were a list of minor league players that were investigated by the MLB for sports betting, and they all were suspended for one year. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leaguers. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego and Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\n___\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB", {"uri": "8159954006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:13:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:13:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:09:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/san-diego-padres-infielder-tucupita-marcano-reportedly-facing-lifetime-ban-for-betting-on-baseball-200000475.html", "title": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano reportedly facing lifetime ban for betting on baseball", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is facing a potential lifetime ban from Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on games, according to The Wall Street Journal.\n\nMarcano allegedly bet on multiple games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season when he was on their injured list. Specifics of those bets aren't yet known. Four other players are also reportedly under investigation for allegedly betting on games in the minor leagues, too.\n\nThough the investigation into Marcano is still ongoing, a decision on the potential lifetime ban \"could be imminent,\" according to ESPN's Jeff Passan.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played for the Padres this season. He went down with a right ACL injury late last season when he was with the Pirates, and he's been recovering ever since. According to the report, Marcano bet on Pirates games after he went down with the injury.\n\nThe Padres, who first signed him out of Venezuela and gave him his major league start in 2021, then signed him to a one-year deal this past offseason.\n\nMarcano, the league and the players association all declined to comment to The Wall Street Journal.\n\nMarcano held a career-high .233 batting average last season with the Pirates. He had 18 RBI, 47 hits and three home runs in 75 games. He tore his ACL in late July, and missed the rest of the season as a result.\n\nThe allegations against Marcano are just the latest in the league and the sports world in general in recent months. Los Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter pleaded guilty to charges after he reportedly stole nearly $17 million from him to cover up illegal gambling losses. Ohtani was not involved in that scandal, which dominated the sport in the lead up to the season.\n\nToronto Raptors player Jontay Porter was given a lifetime ban from the NBA earlier this year, too, after the league said he purposely limited his participation in games for betting purposes and for betting on games. that got him banned...", "body": "The bets that got Tucupita Marcano banned from MLB for life Tuesday weren't even close to being worth it.\n\nThe Padres infielder, who was banned for betting on Pirates games while he was assigned to their major league club last year, did not win any of the 25 bets he placed on Pittsburgh and barely won any of his 231 MLB-related bets, according to the league.\n\n\"Consistent with Marcano's overall baseball betting activity, almost all of Marcano's Pirates bets were on which Club (the Pirates or their opponent) would win the game or whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game,\" MLB said in a release. \"Ultimately, Marcano lost all of his parlays involving the Pirates and only won 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets overall.\"\n\nMarcano, 24, was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, some of which were international games, from Oct. 16, 2022 through Oct. 23, 2022 and July 12, 2023 through Nov. 1, 2023 through a legal sportsbook.\n\nThe Venezuela native, who was named after his hometown, bet more than $150,000 on baseball, which included $87,319 on MLB-related bets.\n\nMarcano didn't appear in any of the Pirates games he bet on, as all of those bets came after his season-ending ACL injury suffered on July 24, 2023, but he was a part of the major league club and received treatment at the team's ballpark.\n\nHe originally signed with the Padres as an international free agent in 2016 at the age of 16.\n\nThe Padres dealt Marcano to the Pirates before the 2021 trade deadline but claimed him off waivers from Pittsburgh this past November after his ACL injury.\n\nA middle infielder who was an occasional fill-in outfielder, Marcano has a career .217/.276/.356 slash line with five home {"uri": "8161339383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:02:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:02:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:01:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/sports/national/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_136c1ea3-feb8-5600-b187-bd4e1598cf7e.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "AP\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nPeople are also reading... Alan Pergament: Kate Welshofer has a new gig at the National Comedy Center Former Channel 2 weather anchor Maria Genero returns to her radio roots on WECK Bills Mailbag: Why Tyler Bass is a cause for concern entering 2024 season At St. Margaret's, some congregants worry about its fate Erie County real estate transactions Buffalo Diocese plans to cut number of parishes by a third in latest restructuring Western New York towns that host prisons wait to see if their facilities will close How the Sabres scouted, drafted QMJHL top defenseman Vsevelod Komarov La'el Collins healthy, eager to show Bills his top tackle form Bills observations: Damar Hamlin shines, secondary clings to WRs downfield Buffalo Bills plan to submit bid to host 2028 NFL draft at new stadium Mats Lindgren among trio of prospects Sabres opt to not sign before deadline Buffalo hires lawyer convicted of filing false documents with IRS to city job Ryan O'Halloran: New number, new position coach, new outlook for Bills cornerback Kaiir Elam Inside the NHL: What has new Seattle coach Dan Bylsma learned in his long wait after firing by Sabres?\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8161266729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:13:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:13:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:12:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-gambling-scandal-padres-tucupita-marcano-banned-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-games/", "title": "MLB gambling scandal: Padres' Tucupita Marcano banned for life for betting on baseball games - CBSSports.com", "body": "Four other players have been suspended for one year each for betting on MLB games Getty Images\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been permanently banned from Major League Baseball after violating the league's gambling policy, MLB announced on Tuesday. Marcano's ban was accompanied by one-year suspensions for four other players.\n\nMLB's press release revealed the following as part of its investigation into Marcano's gambling:\n\nIn total, Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $378 per bet). Of the over 200 MLB bets Marcano placed over this period, 25 of those bets included Pirates games while he was assigned to the Pirates' Major League Club. Marcano did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets, however, because all of Marcano's Pirates-related bets, and the vast majority of his bets overall, occurred during the period after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park.\n\nMarcano, 24, was signed by the Padres as an amateur free agent out of Venezuela in 2016. He was traded to the Pirates in 2021 with Jack Suwinski for Adam Frazier and last November went back to the Padres on waivers. He hasn't played a game in 2024 due to a torn ACL.\n\nMLB rules stipulate that players are permitted to legally gamble on non-diamond sports, but they cannot gamble on baseball or softball at any level. A player caught gambling on teams other than his own faces a one-year suspension for a first offense and a lifetime ban if he's found having gambled on his own team, as Marcano has been accused of.\n\nEarlier this season, Ippei Mizuhara -- Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter -- was charged with stealing more than $16 million from Ohtani to pay off gambling debts to an illegal bookie. He faces a maximum of 33 years in prison. Braves minor-leaguer David Fletcher is also being investigated by MLB for placing bets with the same illegal bookmaker that Mizuhara used. Neither Mizuhara nor Fletcher is alleged to have gambled on baseball, but betting on any sport through illegal channels is also forbidden by MLB.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8160104710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "22:56:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T22:56:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T22:54:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2024/06/tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-for-betting-on-baseball.html", "title": "Tucupita Marcano Under Investigation For Betting On Baseball", "body": "Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for betting on baseball while a member of the Pirates, according to a report from Jared Diamond and Lindsey Adler of The Wall Street Journal. Marcano is facing a lifetime ban. Four other players are under investigation for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues as well, though the identities of those others are not known. The report adds that there's no evidence at this point of games being manipulated.\n\nMarcano, 24, was placed on the injured list by the Pirates in July of last year and eventually underwent surgery to repair the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee. The Padres claimed him off waivers in November and he has been on the injured list for all of 2024 so far, still recovering from that surgery.\n\nPer the report from Diamond and Adler, Marcano \"has been accused of betting on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season while he was on the injured list for that team.\" Per the report, the league and the MLB Players' Association are still discussing Marcano's ultimate punishment but, as mentioned, a lifetime ban is on the table. Marcano, the league and the union all declined to comment for the piece, though the Padres released a statement:\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\u00e2\u20ac\n\nBrian Warecki, Pirates' senior vice president of Communications, also issued a statement, relayed by Noah Hiles of the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette on X. \u00e2\u20ac\u0153We are aware of the matter that\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s under investigation and are fully cooperating. We will refrain from further comment at this time.\u00e2\u20ac\n\nAs relayed by the WSJ piece, the league's gambling policy is prominently displayed in all clubhouses. Baseball players are legally allowed to bet on other sports but not on baseball. A player betting on teams other than his own faces a one-year suspension but betting on a game involving his own team results in a lifetime ban.\n\nGambling scandals have been around almost as long as baseball itself. Most famously, the \"Black Sox Scandal\" saw eight members of the 1919 White Sox were banned for life after being accused of taking bribes from gamblers to throw that year's World Series. MLB's all-time hits leader Pete Rose also received a lifetime ban in 1989 after accusations that he gambled on the Reds during his time as a player and manager.\n\nMore recently, gambling scandals have come back into the spotlight, thanks to a 2018 Supreme Court decision that opened the door for states to legalize the practice. Ippei Mizuhara, the former interpreter for Shohei Ohtani, is in the process of pleading guilty to bank fraud and subscribing to a false tax return in relation to a gambling scandal. To this point, the evidence of that case suggests he didn't bet on baseball. However, he did make bets with an illegal bookmaker in California, where sports betting is still illegal. He is alleged to have stolen millions of dollars from an account in Ohtani's name in order to pay off his debts. David Fletcher of the Braves is also under investigation for placing bets with the same bookmaker as Mizuhara, though Fletcher isn't accused of placing bets on baseball either. Gambling has also been an issue in other sports, with Jontay Porter receiving a ban from the NBA for gambling violations while playing for the Raptors.\n\nMizuhara and Fletcher both bet on other sports in a state where it's illegal, while Mizuhara is also alleged to have committed several financial crimes. MLB commissioner Rob Manfred discussed those situations last month and said the league would be taking a hands-off approach until the legal process played out.\n\nThe Marcano situation would appear to be a different matter. If the accusations are proven to be true and he did indeed bet on the Pirates while a member of the team, it would appear to be a straightforward case where a lifetime ban will be the result. Further details on this case, and the cases of the other four players, will undoubtedly be forthcoming in the future.", "source": {"uri": "mlbtraderumors.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MLB Trade {"uri": "8161437338", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:07:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:07:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:06:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.sportico.com/leagues/baseball/2024/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-betting-baseball-1234782843/", "title": "MLB Bans Tucupita Marcano for Life for Betting on Baseball", "body": "Four other players -- Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, along with three minor league players, Padres pitcher Jay Groome, Phillies infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Diamondbacks pitcher Andrew Saalfrank -- have been declared ineligible for one year for violations of MLB's gambling policy.\n\nAccording to MLB, betting data obtained from a sports betting operator revealed Marcano made 387 bets on baseball between Oct. 16, 2022, and Nov. 1, 2023, including 231 MLB-related bets, while a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates organization. He spent over $150,000 on baseball bets including $87,319 on MLB-bets, with the remaining bets placed on international baseball games.\n\nHe made 25 bets on Pirates games while he was with the major league club, but he did not appear in any of the games on which he bet. Overall, Marcano won 4.3% of his MLB-related bets and lost all of his Pirates parlays.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement.\n\nThe investigation comes on the heels of the NBA permanently banning former Toronto Raptors player Jontay Porter for violating the league's gambling rules. Marcano is the first active participant in MLB declared permanently ineligible since Pete Rose was banned for life while managing the Cincinnati Reds in 1989. MLB previously looked into Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter Ippei Mizuhara for sports betting. {"uri": "8161344864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:05:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:05:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:04:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_008ffb5d-924d-592e-8943-7337091039d5.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nPeople are also reading... Marion police: 649 grams of marijuana, 1.8 grams of cocaine found during traffic stop Two arrested in Marion after traffic stop turns up narcotics Marion man charged in death by distribution case Nebo couple arrested, charged following home raid Nebo Crossing Academy celebrates 15 graduates Missing Davie County woman and her husband found dead Friday. Ashanti Alert was issued Thursday for Cynthia Gobble Marion man charged with shooting into a residence Old Fort's Catawba Falls Trail set to reopen Friday after 2 years closed Traffic stop leads to narcotics arrest by Marion police Greensboro Baptist pastor arrested by FBI, says he will be 'vindicated by God' Woman of color, descendant of John Carson joins McDowell DAR McDowell County Schools Alumni Spotlight: Sheriff Ricky Buchanan McDowell garbage facility, 911 center in running for federal money Reporter, wife, dog have lunch at Switzerland Caf\u00e9 In wake of shootout, Hickory pub featured on 'Bar Rescue' TV show loses liquor license\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Stanley Cup and NBA playoffs, baseball, soccer and more!\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161329116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:54:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:54:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:53:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/sports/mlb/padres-tucupita-marcano-mlb-lifetime-ban-betting/3556603/", "title": "MLB bans Padres' Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball", "body": "Marcano is seemingly the first active major leaguer to be banned for gambling in 100 years. New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell was the last in 1924.\n\nAlong with Marcano's lifetime ban, four other players received one-year suspensions for placing unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook. Oakland A's pitcher Michael Kelly, Padres minor league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank were all found to have violated MLB's gambling policies.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a release. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMLB released information on each player's gambling activity and found that Marcano made 25 bets on Pittsburgh Pirates while he was a member of the MLB club in 2023. {"uri": "8161355225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:11:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:11:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:10:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_b4592f72-08f5-59c3-9768-49aaa36b7255.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nPeople are also reading... Sioux City Marina operator responds to city's lawsuit Little Chicago Deli reopens in Sioux City Friday Woodbury County Court Report for May 28, 2024 SUX Pride creating a festive something for everybody event in Sioux City Updated: Sioux City terminates inclusion liaison Semehar Ghebrekidan East's Mackenzie Crawford is Broadway-bound for a chance at the Jimmys Athlete of the Week: A budding star emerging for SB-L in Moreau Iowa restaurant inspection update: Green slime, moldy meat, unlicensed eateries Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for May 28, 2024 Day-long, downtown event highlights 'So Much To Do' in Sioux City Fatal hit-and-run suspect returned to Sioux City, faces 4 charges Boys state soccer: Heelan captures first state title with OT win over Assumption Nebraska baseball's NCAA tournament run continues after Huskers eliminate Niagara Onawa man pleads not guilty in wife's shooting death Parents of another Hinton wrestler sue coaches, school for alleged assaults\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Stanley Cup and NBA playoffs, baseball, soccer and more!\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8159952475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:09:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:09:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:08:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-gambling-scandal-padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-accused-of-betting-on-baseball-per-report/", "title": "MLB gambling scandal: Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation, accused of betting on baseball, per report - CBSSports.com", "body": "Marcano allegedly bet on games involving his own team while on the IL with the Pirates in 2023 Getty Images\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly violating the league's gambling policy, the Wall Street Journal reports. According to the report, Marcano has been accused of gambling on Pirates games while he was on Pittsburgh's injured list last year. If Marcano is found to have broken the rules, he faces a lifetime ban.\n\nA spokesperson for MLB confirmed to CBS Sports Monday that Marcano is under investigation.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the Padres said in a statement to the WSJ. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nFour minor-league players have also been accused of gambling on MLB games, according to the Journal, which did not name them.\n\nMarcano, 24, was signed by the Padres as an amateur free agent out of Venezuela in 2016. He was traded to the Pirates in 2021 with Jack Suwinski for Adam Frazier and last November went back to the Padres on waivers. He hasn't played a game in 2024 due to a torn ACL.\n\nMLB rules stipulate that players are permitted to legally gamble on non-diamond sports, but they cannot gamble on baseball or softball at any level. A player caught gambling on teams other than his own faces a one-year suspension for a first offense and a lifetime ban if he's found having gambled on his own team, as Marcano has been accused of.",
