{"uri": "8161281662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:23:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:23:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:22:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.tsn.ca/mlb/san-diego-padres-infielder-tucupita-marcano-banned-for-life-over-gambling-violation-1.2129901", "title": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano banned for life over gambling violation | TSN", "body": "Major League Baseball meted out discipline for five players on Tuesday in relation to violations of the league's betting rules.\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been ruled permanently ineligible and banned for life after placing 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, an investigation found.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly received a one-year ban, as did Padres minor-league pitcher Jay Groome, Philadelphia Phillies minor-leaguer Jose Rodriguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor-league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank.\n\nAccording to the investigation, Marcano wagered $87,319 on MLB-related bets, including 25 bets on the Pittsburgh Pirates while part of the Pirates roster. Marcano did not feature in any of the games on which he wagered. There is no evidence to suggest that any of the games' outcomes were compromised.\n\nA native of Tucupita, Venezuela, Marcano did not appear in any major league games in 2024. In three big league seasons from 2021 to 2023, Marcano played in 149 games, batting .217 with 88 hits, five home runs, 34 runs batted in and an OPS of .589.\n\nKelly, 31, was in his third season in the majors and first with the A's. {"uri": "8161490728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:43:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:43:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/maurybrown/2024/06/04/tucupita-marcano-banishment-for-betting-on-baseball-shows-sports-leagues-are-dancing-with-the-devil/", "title": "Tucupita Marcano Banishment From MLB For Betting Shows Sports Leagues Are Dancing With The Devil", "body": "San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano has been declared permanently ineligible for violating MLB's sports betting rules. He becomes the first MLB player since Pete Rose in 1989 to be banned under the league's rules and policies. As sports leagues have become tightly integrated with the gaming industry, betting scandals are going to become the norm.\n\nAccording to MLB, Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets, as well as bets on international baseball play over the course of a week in October of 2022 and from July 12, 2023 through November 1, 2023. All told, he wagered more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets. During that time he was with the Pittsburgh Pirates. According to the league, he consistently wagered on parlays, some of which were the Pirates. Marcano lost all of his parlays involving the Pirates and only won 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets overall.\n\nThe league states that - and Marcano denies - that he influenced play to alter game outcomes.\n\nOn top of Marcano, MLB announced that other players, Michael Kelly (Oakland Athletics pitcher); and Minor League players Jay Groome (Padres pitcher), Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez (Philadelphia Phillies infielder) and Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher) declared ineligible for one year for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies.\n\nAll bets were made through a legal sports betting operator.\n\nMajor League Baseball has had strict rules and policies around players wagering on baseball and other sports since the 1919 \"Black Sox\" scandal that centered on eight players that, to one level or another, were deemed to be altering game outcomes by an investigation by the first commissioner for Major League Baseball, Kennesaw \"Mountain\" Landis. Since then, Rule 21 has been in place which states that any MLB player found to have gambled on baseball can face lifetime banishment from the sport.\n\nIn 2018, when the U.S. Supreme Court struck down federal law that prohibited sports betting, it opened the floodgates for all the major sports leagues to reach lucrative partnerships with the gaming industry. With media outlets becoming integrated, the stage was set for sports betting scandals to flourish.\n\nAs part of Major League Baseball's statement on Marcano and the other players involved in betting, they placed the onus on the players saying \"requires its personnel to participate annually in sports betting education programs that reiterate the policies applicable to respective groups\" and went onto to say that players must attend in-person sessions that are in both English and Spanish that specify the requirements of Major League Rule 21 and MLB's Sports Betting Policy as well as other best practices.\n\nWith players being often young and impressionable, the ease of wagering via smartphones, and the bombardment of sports wagering opportunities across all forms of media, the sports leagues have opened Pandora's Box. Beyond today's MLB discipline, the following has either occurred or is in the midst of investigation within roughly the past year:\n\nThe first professional player in North American sports to be banned permanently for sports betting since the U.S. Supreme Court decision in 2018 was Josh Shaw of the Arizona Cardinals. While he was the first in this new era of making sports betting so vastly available, he is just the beginning of what will be more scandals.\n\nWhile today's news of Tucupita Marcano banishment is the latest, at what point will the 1919 Black Sox scandal be revisited? Could the Super Bowl, or NBA Finals, or the Stanley Cup Finals be jeopardized in the future due to sports wagering becoming foisted on not just fans, but the players? When the major sports leagues opted to take the revenues from the sports wagering industry, the dance with the devil was part of that calculus. That dance appears to have the tempo increasing.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The other players were identified as Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly and Minor League players Jay Groome (Padres pitcher), Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez (Philadelphia Phillies infielder) and Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher), all of whom received one-year bans.\n\nBetting data shows that Marcano \"placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets among other bets on international baseball games through a legal sportsbook\" from October 16, 2022 through October 23, 2022, which included 25 on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates, his team at the time, most of which occurred during the period in which he suffered a season-ending knee injury. MLB Rule 21 states that \"any player or person connected with a club\" who bets on games involving their own team is subject to a lifetime ban, as was the case for MLB hit king Pete Rose, who remains banned from the game and the Baseball Hall of Fame for gambling during his tenure as the Cincinnati Reds' manager.\n\nMarcano was reported to have bet more than $150,000 on baseball, including $87,319 He was traded to the Pirates in 2021 and returned to the Padres on waivers last November.\n\nShould he be found guilty of betting on baseball, Marcano could face a lifetime ban. According to the Wall Street Journal, who first reported on the ongoing investigation Monday afternoon, a penalty could be imminent.\n\nThe betting allegations against Marcano come in a season where gambling has loomed large.\n\nLos Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani's longtime interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was accused of stealing more than $16 million from the designated hitter to pay off debts with an illegal bookmarker. The accusations escalated to federal charges of bank and tax fraud last month, which Mizuhara pleaded guilty to after reaching a deal with prosecutors.\n\nAccording to the Wall Street Journal, MLB officials are also investigating Ohtani's teammate from the Los Angeles Angels, David Fletcher, who is accused of using the same illegal bookmarker to bet on sports.\n\nFour other minor league players are also under investigation for baseball betting, the report added, but names and affiliation were not disclosed. However, the report noted that there is no evidence this alleged betting led to game manipulation.\n\nNexstar's KSWB/KUSI has reached out to MLB for further comment on the investigation.", "source": We will refrain from further comment at this time.\"\n\nBetting scandals marred the start of the baseball season this year after news dropped over the millions of dollars lost by Dodgers' Shohei Ohtani. {"uri": "8161363740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:16:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:16:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:15:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/professional/mlb/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year/article_cd65571d-5b7b-50e2-abfe-fc65fe1bb3e5.html", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "AP\n\nNEW YORK -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nPeople are also reading... 'The Real Housewives of Napa Valley' debuts Friday Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Napa city Planning Commissioner Bob Massaro dies 'We feel identified': Thousands flock to Napa for La Onda's Latin music showcase Car rolls over on Highway 29 in Napa Napa's Oxbow RiverStage concert series goes on hiatus as promoters seek new site Your guide to Festival La Onda: What to watch for, and how to get around downtown Napa BottleRock organizers tap into the Latino market with Festival La Onda Letter: Concerned for the future of the wine industry NFL: Former Vintage High lineman and Super Bowl champion Allen dies at age 52 American Canyon High School student arrested after gun found in car Festival La Onda takes a bow Sunday, concludes Napa debut Napa doctor launches concierge medical practice and fights obesity epidemic Latin music, Latino fans gained the Napa spotlight at La Onda Napa Police seeks information about motorcyclist reported missing\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on - testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"\n\nMarcano was found to have placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers, between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. The league says 25 of those bets included wagers on Pittsburgh Pirates games while he was on the team's major league roster. However, he did not appear in any of those games because he was on the injured list following a season-ending knee injury. He was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park during that time. Marcano bet almost exclusively on the outcomes of games and lost all of his parlay bets involving the Pirates, winning just 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Stanley Cup and NBA playoffs, baseball, soccer and more!\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. That came during this past NBA regular season.\n\nAs for Marcano ... well, he may not be alone.\n\n\"Four other minor league players are facing potential discipline for gambling as well,\" Passan wrote, citing sources. \"Even if a player in the minor leagues is on a team's 40-man roster, he would face a one-year suspension for gambling on major league games, according to Rule 21.\"\n\nPro sports just recently got in bed with the gamblers and bookies, making it legal to bet on the games. That ruling, of course, was supposed to be limited to fans.\n\nBut the MLB is under extra scrutiny, given that Pete Rose was banned for betting on games years ago. four others suspended one...", "body": "Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was officially banned from MLB for life on Tuesday for betting on Pirates games while he was a member of the team last season, commissioner Rob Manfred announced.\n\nFour other players -- A's pitcher Michael Kelly, Diamondbacks pitcher Andrew Saalfrank, Padres pitcher Jay Groome and Phillies infielder Jose Rodriguez -- received one-year suspensions for betting on other teams.\n\nMarcano was found to have bet on the Pirates while he was on their injured list.\n\nThe 24-year-old, whom Spotrac projects has made $2.7 million during his baseball career, has a career .217 average and .589 OPS in 149 games.\n\nKelly, 31, is in his first season with the Athletics after pitching for the Guardians last year and the Phillies in 2022.\n\nHe has a 2.59 ERA in 28 appearances this season.\n\nSaalfrank, 26, spent parts of the last two seasons with the Diamondbacks, last giving up four runs in \u2153 inning on April 29 before being demoted to Triple-A Reno on May 1.\n\nThe lefty specialist played a rather important role with the club during their surprise World Series run last fall, giving up three runs (two earned) in 5 \u2154 innings across 11 appearances, including Games 2, 3 and 4 of the World Series.\n\nSpotrac projects that Saalfrank made $361,341 in his playing career up until this point, but signed a fully guaranteed one-year $740,000 deal this past offseason.\n\nMarcano was signed as a 16-year-old out of Venezuela in 2016 by the Padres before being traded to the Pirates in 2021.\n\nHe lasted played in a big league game in July 2023, when he tore his ACL while running the bases.\n\nIt's another massive blow to baseball, which has been embroiled in gambling scandals this season.\n\nShohei Ohtani's former interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was charged in April with stealing more than $16 million from the Dodgers superstar to pay off debts from bets made with an illegal bookie.\n\nOhtani's ex-Angels teammate David Fletcher is also under investigation by MLB for allegedly placing bets through the same illegal bookmaker.\n\nAccording to Rule 21.(d) in the MLB official handbook regarding misconduct: \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nThey also lay out the groundwork for betting legally versus illegally.\n\nFletcher, who was a member of the Los Angeles Angels last season, was residing in California, which does not have legal sports betting.\n\n\"Betting on any sport illegally is forbidden,\" the MLB handbook regarding misconduct continues. \"But players are allowed to bet legally on every sport except for baseball. Betting on a baseball game involving teams other than the player's own team results in a one-year suspension, while betting on a game involving the player's own team results in a lifetime ban.\"\n\nPete Rose received a lifetime ban in 1989 after he was found to have placed bets on the Reds to win from 1985-87 while playing for and managing the team.\n\nThe NBA banned Raptors forward {"uri": "2024-06-377684016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:52:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:52:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:46:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://whnt.com/news/san-diego-padres-player-facing-lifetime-ban-for-alleged-sports-betting-reports/", "title": "San Diego Padres player facing lifetime ban for alleged sports betting: reports", "body": "SAN DIEGO (KSWB/KUSI) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball officials for allegedly violating the league's gambling policy, according to multiple reports.\n\nMarcano, who joined the Padres in the offseason from the Pittsburgh Pirates and has spent the season thus far on the long-term injured list, has been accused of gambling on games shortly after sustaining a season-ending ACL injury in July of last year.\n\nIn a statement, Padres officials said they were aware of the investigation \"regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres.\"\n\n\"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed,\" the statement continued.\n\nThe Associated Press reported that MLB is looking into the allegations, citing a source who spoke on condition of anonymity due to the ongoing investigation.\n\nMarcano was first signed by the Padres as an amateur free agent from Venezuela in 2016. He was traded to the Pirates in 2021 and returned to the Padres on waivers last November.\n\nShould he be found guilty of betting on baseball, the 24-year-old could face a lifetime ban, ESPN and the Wall Street Journal reported. According to the Wall Street Journal, which first reported on the ongoing investigation Monday afternoon, a penalty could be imminent.\n\nThe betting allegations against Marcano come in a season where gambling has loomed large.\n\nLos Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani's longtime interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, was accused of stealing more than $16 million from the designated hitter to pay off debts with an illegal bookmarker. The accusations escalated to federal charges of bank and tax fraud last month, which Mizuhara pleaded guilty to after reaching a deal with prosecutors.\n\nAccording to the Wall Street Journal, MLB officials are also investigating Ohtani's teammate from the Los Angeles Angels, David Fletcher, who is accused of using the same illegal bookmarker to bet on sports.\n\nFour other minor league players are also under investigation for baseball betting, the report added, but names and affiliations were not disclosed. However, the report noted that there is no evidence this alleged betting led to game manipulation.\n\nNexstar's KSWB/KUSI has reached out to MLB for further comment on the investigation.", "source": Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano found himself on the receiving end of the ban hammer, courtesy of MLB's zero-tolerance policy on gambling shenanigans.\n\nThe saga began with a whisper and escalated into a roar when the Wall Street Journal spilled the beans on an investigation into Marcano's gambling escapades. Hot on the trail, MLB didn't waste any time in dropping the hammer, announcing Marcano's lifetime ban faster than you can say \"strike three.\"\n\nBut Marcano isn't the lone ranger in this high-stakes drama; oh no, he's just the tip of the iceberg. Rumor has it that four other players are feeling the heat of MLB's probing gaze, their own futures hanging in the balance like a knuckleball in the wind.\n\nAnd let's not forget the NBA's brush with the dark side of gambling, a cautionary tale starring Raptors forward Jontay Porter. Permanently banned from the league for betting against himself, Porter's fall from grace serves as a chilling reminder of the stakes involved in this high-stakes game.\n\nWhile Marcano and Porter may not be household names, their tales serve as a sobering reality check for the world of professional sports. Imagine the chaos if a bigger fish were caught in the net of gambling violations - a crisis of epic proportions, the likes of which would make the Black Sox scandal look like child's play.\n\nBut why Marcano? What led MLB to wield the ban hammer with such gusto? Let's peel back the layers of this mystery and delve into the enigmatic world of Tucupita Marcano.\n\nIn the fast-paced realm of sports gambling, where fair competition can quickly turn into cheating, Major League Baseball is taking strong measures to address the issue. Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned by MLB for involvement in gambling activities due to their strict policy.\n\nThe story started quietly but quickly grew louder when the Wall Street Journal exposed an inquiry into Marcano's gambling activities. MLB wasted no time in announcing Marcano's lifetime ban, taking swift action on the matter.\n\nHowever, Marcano is not the only person involved in this intense situation; he is just the beginning of a bigger issue. Rumor has it that four additional players are under scrutiny by MLB, their futures uncertain like a knuckleball swirling in the wind. Banned from the league for life for betting against himself, Porter's downfall is a stark reminder of the risks in this high-stakes game.\n\nThough not well-known, Marcano and Porter's stories offer a stark reminder of the harsh realities present in the professional sports industry. Picture the pandemonium if a larger fish was ensnared in the web of gambling infractions - a huge crisis that would dwarf the Black Sox scandal in comparison.\n\nMarcano made his first appearance in the MLB with the Padres at the young age of 21 in the year 2021. He was exchanged to the Pirates in a trade during the middle of the season which included sending Adam Frazier to San Diego.\n\nMarcano seized a chance to get some playing time in Pittsburgh, featuring in 49 games in 2022. However, he only managed to hit .206 with two home runs and a .562 OPS. Marcano batted .233 and had a .633 OPS in 75 games during the 2023 season before tearing his ACL. {"uri": "2024-06-378524493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:23:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:23:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:15:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.kob.com/news/us-and-world-news/mlb-bans-tucupita-marcano-for-life-for-betting-on-baseball-four-others-get-one-year-suspensions/", "title": "MLB bans Tucupita Marcano for life for betting on baseball, four others get one-year suspensions", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Major League Baseball permanently banned San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano on Tuesday for betting on baseball and suspended four other players for one year after finding the players placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\n\nMarcano appears to be the first active major leaguer banned under the sport's gambling provision since New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell in 1924. Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leaguers. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego and Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez of Philadelphia were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161435001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:07:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:07:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:04:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/06/04/mlb-betting-issues-tucupita-mercano", "title": "MLB hands down lifetime ban to Padres' Marcano for betting on baseball", "body": "MLB today \"permanently banned\" Padres SS Tucupita Marcano for betting on baseball, a move that appears to make him the first active player in 100 years to be banned \"under the sport's gambling provision,\" according to the AP. Four other players -- A's P Michael Kelly and three minor leaguers -- were suspended for one year after it was found they \"placed unrelated bets with a legal sportsbook.\" MLB indicated that it was \"tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator.\" None of the players \"played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on.\" Marcano was found to have \"placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related wagers,\" between Oct. 16, 2022 and Nov. 1, 2023, totaling over $150,000. Twenty-five of those bets included Pirates games \"while he was on the team's major league roster,\" though he was out with a season-ending knee injury at that time (AP, 6/4). The WALL STREET JOURNAL's Diamond & Adler, who first broke the Marcano news, noted this punishment comes amid a \"rapidly widening net\" of gambling scandals that have enveloped American sports. The NBA in April banned Raptors C Jontay Porter for violating the league's gambling policy, including \"providing confidential information to bettors and limiting his own participation for betting purposes\" (WALL STREET JOURNAL, 6/3).\n\nA GROWING CONCERN: In D.C., Chelsea James noted the investigation into Marcano is the \"latest concern\" amid the widespread legalization of sports gambling in the U.S. The issue \"exploded into public view\" in March when news broke that Ippei Mizuhara, the interpreter for Dodgers P/DH Shohei Ohtani, had \"siphoned millions away\" to pay off gambling debts. Though MLB \"plasters clubhouse doors with warnings against betting on baseball and ensures teams spend spring training mornings drilling that rule into the players' heads,\" it has \"never been {"uri": "8160014291", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:11:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:11:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:10:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/06/mlb-player-faces-lifetime-ban-for-gambling-and-4-others-are-in-mlbs-crosshairs.html", "title": "MLB player faces lifetime ban for gambling  --  and 4 others are in MLB's crosshairs", "body": "The MLB continues to be at the spotlight of sports gambling issues.\n\nSan Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues for the Pittsburgh Pirates last season, along with four other players whose identities have not been confirmed, according to the Wall Street Journal.\n\nThe report also said there is no evidence of game manipulation, though if guilty, Marcano will be banned for life from MLB.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the Padres said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano signed to the Padres as an international free agent in 2016, was traded to the Pirates in 2021 for Adam Frazier, before being released in 2023 and re-signed by the Padres this year.\n\nBaseball has already seen a number of gambling investigations this year. U.S. prosecutors charged Shohei Ohtani's former interpreter Ippei Mizuhara for stealing $16 million of Ohtani's money to pay debts accrued from placing bets with an illegal bookie, and former Los Angeles Angles infielder David Fletcher is under investigation for making bets with that bookmaker.\n\nThe names of the four other players under investigation have yet to be revealed, which means there is a chance one could be a Yankee or Met.\n\nNo Yankees or Mets player has been accused of gambling, but with it being legal in New York, it is possible for a player to easily bet on sports.\n\nThe last player to be banned from MLB was Mets pitcher Jenrry Mej\u00eda, who was banned in 2016 for testing positive for PEDs in 2016, but was later reinstated in 2016. The NBA banned Raptors forward Jontay Porter for life in April for violating the league's gambling policy.\n\nThank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. {"uri": "8161307842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:40:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:40:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:39:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.bleedcubbieblue.com/2024/6/4/24171196/athletics-pitcher-michael-kelly-four-others-disciplined-by-mlb-betting-on-baseball", "title": "A's pitcher Michael Kelly, four others disciplined by MLB for betting on baseball", "body": "Monday, a Wall Street Journal article by Jared Diamond and Lindsey Adler revealed that former MLB player Tucupita Marcano (now in the Padres organization on their injured list) might face a lifetime ban from the sport for violating Rule 21, the MLB rule that forbids betting on baseball. That rule states:\n\n\"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year.\" Whereas, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nToday, the league did announce that lifetime ban for Marcano and also disciplined four other players, including Michael Kelly, a righthanded reliever currently on the Oakland Athletics' MLB roster, for betting on baseball. MLB's press release states:\n\nIn March 2024, MLB learned from a legal sports betting operator that it had identified past baseball betting activity from accounts connected to multiple Major and Minor League players. MLB obtained data from that operator and other sportsbooks, including authentication data for bets. None of these players played in any game on which they placed a bet. Further, all of the players denied that they had any inside information relevant to the bets or that any of the baseball games they bet on were compromised or manipulated, and the betting data does not suggest that any outcomes in the baseball games on which they placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way. None of the players are appealing their discipline.\n\nHere are MLB's official statements about Marcano and the other four players.\n\nSan Diego Padres Major League infielder/outfielder Tucupita Marcano has been declared permanently ineligible for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies, including Rule 21(d)(2).\n\nBetting data shows that from October 16, 2022 through October 23, 2022, and from July 12, 2023 through November 1, 2023, Marcano placed 387 baseball bets, including 231 MLB-related bets among other bets on international baseball games through a legal sportsbook. Marcano's MLB bets were generally parlays, which would sometimes include multiple MLB-related legs, and they would sometimes include MLB-related legs and non-MLB legs.\n\nIn total, Marcano bet more than $150,000 on baseball, with $87,319 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $378 per bet). Of the over 200 MLB bets Marcano placed over this period, 25 of those bets included Pirates games while he was assigned to the Pirates' Major League Club. Marcano did not appear in any of the games on which he placed bets, however, because all of Marcano's Pirates-related bets, and the vast majority of his bets overall, occurred during the period after he suffered a season-ending knee injury on July 24, 2023 and was receiving medical treatment at PNC Park.\n\nConsistent with Marcano's overall baseball betting activity, almost all of Marcano's Pirates bets were on which Club (the Pirates or their opponent) would win the game or whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game. Ultimately, Marcano lost all of his parlays involving the Pirates and only won 4.3% of all of his MLB-related bets overall.\n\nThere is no evidence to suggest -- and Marcano denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\n\nOakland Athletics Major League pitcher Michael Kelly has been declared ineligible for one year for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies, including Rule 21(d)(1).\n\nBetting data shows that from October 5, 2021 through October 17, 2021, Kelly, who at the time was a Minor League player assigned to the Houston Astros' Triple-A affiliate in Sugar Land, Texas, placed 10 bets involving nine MLB games, including bets on the outcomes, over/under bets on the number of runs scored, and on an individual pitcher's strikeout total. Three of the nine games on which Kelly placed bets involved the Houston Astros Major League Club.\n\nKelly's account bet $99.22 on MLB games (an average of $9.92 per bet). Overall, Kelly won five of the MLB game bets and had a net win of $28.30 on the bets.\n\nKelly did not appear in any of the games on which he bet, and he did not make any bets involving his assigned team. There is no evidence to suggest -- and Kelly denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\n\nArizona Diamondbacks Minor League pitcher Andrew Saalfrank has been declared ineligible for one year for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies, including Rule 21(d)(1).\n\nBetting data shows that from September 9, 2021 through October 29, 2021, and on March 9, 2022, Saalfrank placed 29 baseball bets, including 28 MLB-related bets and one parlay bet on college baseball games, while he was on a Minor League contract with the Diamondbacks. Saalfrank placed all of his MLB-related bets, including four bets involving the Diamondbacks' Major League team, while he was assigned to and on the Injured List of the Diamondbacks' Low-A affiliate.\n\nIn total, Saalfrank bet $445.87 on baseball, with $444.07 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $15.86 per bet) and with a net loss of $272.64 on MLB bets. Ultimately, Saalfrank only won five of his 28 MLB-related bets and lost his $1.80 college bet.\n\nSaalfrank's MLB bets included parlays, which sometimes included multiple MLB-related legs and would sometimes include MLB-related legs and non-MLB legs. Saalfrank's bets varied, including who would win the game, the over/under of strikeouts by a pitcher, or whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game.\n\nSaalfrank did not appear in any of the games on which he bet, and he did not make any bets involving his assigned team. There is no evidence to suggest -- and Saalfrank denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\n\nSaalfrank pitched in 10 games for the Diamondbacks last year, including four against the Cubs, and also in the postseason for Arizona, including the World Series. He pitched in two games for the D-backs this year.\n\nPhiladelphia Phillies Minor League infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez has been declared ineligible for one year for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies, including Rule 21(d)(1).\n\nBetting data shows that on September 30, 2021, and from June 5, 2022 through July 30, 2022, Rodr\u00edguez placed 31 baseball bets, comprised of three bets on college baseball games and 28 MLB-related bets while he was on a Minor League contract with the Chicago White Sox. His MLB bets included seven bets involving the White Sox' Major League team while he was assigned to the White Sox' Double-A affiliate in Birmingham, Alabama. Two Club-related bets involved the outcomes and his other Club-related bets were on whether there would be more or less than a certain number of runs scored in the game.\n\nIn total, Rodr\u00edguez bet $749.09 on baseball, with $724.09 of that on MLB-related bets (an average of approximately $25.86 per bet). His MLB bets included parlays, which sometimes included multiple MLB-related legs and would sometimes include MLB-related legs and non-MLB legs.\n\nRodr\u00edguez did not appear in any of the games on which he bet, and he did not make any bets involving his assigned team. There is no evidence to suggest -- and Rodr\u00edguez denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\n\nAs noted above, Rodriguez was in the White Sox organization at the time he placed these bets. He played in one MLB game for the Sox last June, and this April was acquired by the Phillies for cash considerations.\n\nPadres Minor League pitcher Jay Groome has been declared ineligible for one year for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies, including Rule 21(d)(1).\n\nBetting data shows that from July 22, 2020 through July 24, 2021, Groome placed 32 MLB-related bets. Of those, 24 bets involved the Red Sox Major League Club, all of which Groome placed while he was assigned to the Red Sox' High-A affiliate in Greenville, South Carolina. All 24 of Groome's Red Sox bets were on the final outcome.\n\nIn total, Groome bet $453.74 on 30 MLB game-related bets (an average of approximately $15.12 per bet) and had a net loss of $433.54 on these bets. Ultimately, Groome only received payouts on two of his MLB bets.\n\nGroome's MLB bets included parlays, which sometimes included multiple MLB-related legs and would sometimes include MLB-related legs and non-MLB legs.\n\nGroome did not appear in any of the games on which he bet, and he did not make any bets involving his assigned team. There is no evidence to suggest -- and Groome denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced, or manipulated in any way.\n\nGroome was the Red Sox' No. 1 pick (12th overall) in the 2016 Draft out of high school in New Jersey. He has played several years in the Red Sox and Padres organizations but has never played in the major leagues.\n\nObviously, none of this is any good, and the hope is that these moves by MLB will discourage other players from betting on baseball. In recent years, since sports gambling was legalized by a 2018 Supreme Court ruling, Major League Baseball has made quite a number of deals with gambling entities, including some teams (the Cubs, for one) opening sports books in or near their ballparks. The explosion of sports gambling was apparently too much temptation for these players. I certainly hope this doesn't continue going forward. MLB said in its release:\n\nMLB requires its personnel to participate annually in sports betting education programs that reiterate the policies applicable to respective groups. Each Spring Training, all Major League and Minor League players must attend in-person sessions that specify the requirements of Major League Rule 21 and MLB's Sports Betting Policy as well as other best practices. MLB hosts a wide array of other English and Spanish awareness programing that reaches players as they begin their professional baseball careers, as they near the Major Leagues, and as they begin each new season. MLB's efforts also include in-person sessions for Minor League players and other baseball employees on avoiding gambling-related harms in their professional and personal lives.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8161464580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:25:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:25:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:24:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.sg/tucupita-marcano-banned-mlb-life-betting-baseball-four-others-handed-one-year-suspension-74822", "title": "Tucupita Marcano Banned from MLB for Life for Betting on Baseball; Four Others Handed One-Year Suspension", "body": "The Padres signed Marcano in 2016 when he was 16 years old out of Venezuela and in 2021, he was traded to the Pirates.\n\nPadres infielder Tucupita Marcano was officially banned from MLB for life on Tuesday for betting on Pirates games while on the team the previous season, commissioner Rob Manfred announced. Marcano was found to have placed a bet on the Pirates while he was listed as injured.\n\nPitchers Michael Kelly of the A's, Andrew Saalfrank of the Diamondbacks, Jay Groome of the Padres, and infielder Jose Rodriguez of the Phillies were handed a one-year suspension each for their involvement in betting on other teams. Marcano, 24, who according to Spotrac has made over $2.7 million in his baseball career, has played in 149 games and has a lifetime.217 average and.589 OPS.\n\nBanned for Life\n\nKelly, 31, pitched for the Phillies in 2022 and the Guardians in 2022 before joining the Athletics for the first time. After 28 outings this season, his ERA is 2.59.\n\nThe 26-year-old Saalfrank played with the Diamondbacks for a portion of the previous two seasons. On April 29, he gave up four runs in a half-inning before being sent to Triple-A Reno on May 1.\n\nIn his 11 appearances, including Games 2, 3, and 4 of the World Series, the left-handed specialist gave up three runs (two earned) in 5 \u2154 innings, playing a major role in the team's unexpected World Series run last autumn.\n\nAccording to Spotrac, Saalfrank earned $361,341 during his playing career until now. However, this past summer, he inked a $740,000 one-year contract that was fully guaranteed.\n\nAs for the two minor leaguers, Spotrac projects that neither Jay Groome nor Jose Rodriguez ever made it to the major leagues, and it appears that neither player's career earnings were disclosed.\n\nEnd of the Road\n\nThe Padres signed Marcano in 2016 when he was 16 years old out of Venezuela and in 2021, he was traded to the Pirates. When he was jogging the bases in July 2023, he tore his ACL, ending his career as a major league player.\n\nBaseball, which has been marred by gambling scandals this season, has suffered yet another severe setback.\n\nIppei Mizuhara, the former interpreter for Shohei Ohtani, was accused in April of robbing the Dodgers star of almost $16 million in order to settle debts from wagers placed through an unauthorized bookmaker.\n\nMLB is also investigating David Fletcher, Ohtani's former teammate with the Angels, for allegedly using the same illicit bookmaker to place bets.\n\nAccording to Rule 21.(d) in the MLB official handbook regarding misconduct: \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nThey also set the foundation for lawful vs unlawful betting.\n\nFletcher was living in California, a state without legal sports betting, and was a member of the Los Angeles Angels the previous season.\n\n\"Betting on any sport illegally is forbidden,\" the MLB handbook regarding misconduct continues. \"But players are allowed to bet legally on every sport except for baseball. Betting on a baseball game involving teams other than the player's own team results in a one-year suspension, while betting on a game involving the player's own team results in a lifetime ban.\"\n\nIn April, the NBA permanently banned Raptors forward Jontay Porter for giving insider information to gamblers and tampering with his playing time to influence wagers.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.sg", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times, Singapore Edition"}, "authors": [{"uri": "r_ghosh@ibtimes.sg", "name": "R. Per this morning's press release:\n\nUnder Major League Rule 21, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year.\" Whereas, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\nMLB's investigation found that from Oct. 16-23, 2022 and from July 12 to November 1, 2023, Marcano placed 387 bets on baseball, including 25 bets on Pirates games where he was a member of Pittsburgh's roster. All 25 of those Pirates bets came while Marcano was rehabbing from a season-ending ACL tear, so he did not appear in any of the games in question. The bets nonetheless violate the league policy and have thus triggered the lifetime ban.\n\nMajor League Baseball also announced that Athletics right-hander Michael Kelly, Diamondbacks lefty Andrew Saalfrank, Padres minor league pitcher Jay Groome and Phillies minor league infielder Jose Rodriguez have been given one-year bans for violating Rule 21(d)(1). All four players were found to have made bets on Major League Baseball games but were not on the Major League roster or injured list of any teams involved in the bets they placed.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8160171922", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "00:22:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T00:22:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T00:21:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/06/03/lifetime-ban-padres-infielder-tucupita-marcano-betting-mlb-games/", "title": "Lifetime Ban Looms For Padres Infielder Tucupita Marcano For Allegedly Betting On MLB Games", "body": "Major League Baseball (MLB) is currently investigating Tucupita Marcano for allegedly violating the league's strict gambling policies, the Wall Street Journal (WSJ) reported Monday.\n\nThe 24-year-old Venezuelan native could face a lifetime ban depending on the results of an ongoing investigation, according to WSJ. The probe accuses San Diego Padres infielder Marcano of betting on MLB games featuring the Pittsburgh Pirates last season while he was on the injured list. Details of the investigation are still being finalized as MLB and the MLB Players Association continue negotiations.\n\nMarcano's representative chose not to comment. The MLB and the MLBPA also refrained from commenting. The San Diego Padres released a statement acknowledging the investigation but noted the incidents allegedly occurred while Marcano was with another team.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres. We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed,\" the San Diego Padres said in a statement, WSJ reported.\n\nMarcano's last appearance in an MLB game was July 24, 2023, for the Pirates, before suffering a season-ending knee injury, the outlet stated. He began his MLB career with the Padres in 2021 after signing as a 16-year-old from Venezuela in 2016 and has played 149 games in the major leagues, batting .217 with five home runs. (RELATED: Rising MLB Star Wants To Join Military After Career Is Over, Coach Says)\n\nThis probe is part of a larger trend of gambling-related issues in sports following the Supreme Court's decision six years ago that legalized sports betting in the U.S., according to WSJ. For instance, the National Basketball Association recently banned a player for gambling violations, and federal prosecutors have charged a high-profile baseball interpreter with embezzling funds to {"uri": "8160016041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:14:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:14:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:12:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/03/sports/mlb-betting-tucupita-marcano-lifetime-ban/", "title": "Major leaguer Tucupita Marcano under investigation for betting on baseball, could face lifetime ban - The Boston Globe", "body": "Marcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal, which also reported four other players face potential discipline for betting on baseball while in the minor leagues.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official, or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension. Betting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to {"uri": "2024-06-377631045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:25:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:25:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:06:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/sports/mlb/major-league-baseball-player-under-investigation-betting-faces-lifetime-ban-reports-1907689", "title": "MLB Player Under Investigation for Betting Faces Lifetime Ban: Report", "body": "According to multiple reports Monday, San Diego Padres utility player Tucupita Marcano is being investigated by Major League Baseball for violating the sport's gambling policy, and he faces the possibility of a lifetime ban.\n\nAccording to the initial report in the Wall Street Journal, Marcano has been accused of betting on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates last season while he was on the injured list for that team.\n\nMarcano, 24, is currently on the Padres' injured list while recovering from knee surgery.\n\nIn parts of three major league seasons with the Padres and Pirates from 2021-23, Marcano has played 149 games and hit .217 with five home runs and 34 RBIs. He has seen time at five different positions and stolen seven bases in his career.\n\nThe Pirates placed Marcano on waivers after last season and he was claimed by the Padres on Nov. 2, 2023, reuniting him with the organization that signed him to a minor league contract out of Venezuela in 2016.\n\nThe history of baseball's gambling-related controversies dates to the early 20th century, when it was common for players to wager on games with bookmakers outside of the ballpark. The American and National Leagues attempted to crack down on the practice under Kennesaw Mountain Landis, the former federal judge who was appointed baseball's first commissioner in 1920.\n\nAmong Landis' first acts: banning for life eight members of the 1919 Chicago White Sox team who were accused of throwing that year's World Series to the Cincinnati Reds. The so-called \"Black Sox Scandal\" cast a pall over the sport and sent a warning to future players who sought to profit off their own performance through side bets: do it again, and you're out.\n\nBaseball's strict no-gambling policy has claimed several players over the years. In 1947, MLB suspended the manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, Leo Durocher, for a year for his relationships with gamblers.\n\nIn 1970, the league suspended Detroit Tigers pitcher Denny McLain for his gambling ties. Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle were later banned from baseball for earning money from Atlantic City Casinos in jobs that essentially amounted to \"greeter.\" Their bans were later revoked.\n\nThe most famous player banned under baseball's policy is Pete Rose, the game's all-time hits leader who remains under a lifetime ban at the age of 83. Rose was the manager of the Cincinnati Reds when he was accused of wagering on major league games; he only confessed to the crime more than a decade later. Rose has applied for reinstatement on multiple occasions but has been denied each time.\n\nAgainst this backdrop, the outlook for Marcano is fairly cut and dried. If he is found guilty of gambling on baseball, his road back into the sport is all but nonexistent.\n\nIf he is cleared of any wrongdoing, Marcano will serve as yet another warning shot across the bow for a sport who has loosened its relationship with professional gambling operations in recent years. MLB (and some teams individually) have official business relationships with DraftKings and MGM, among others.\n\nIn March, the interpreter for Los Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani, Ippei Mizuhara, confessed to wagering millions of Ohtani's money through an illegal bookmaker over a span of years. Mizuhara is expected to plead guilty in court this year.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jon_paul_hoornstra@newsweek.com", "name": {"uri": "8160034058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:32:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:32:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:32:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.covers.com/industry/mlb-marcano-sports-betting-violation-possible-ban-june-2024", "title": "WSJ Reports MLB Eyeing Infielder for Sports Betting Violations", "body": "Yet another gambling-related incident for a sports governing body came to light Monday after the Wall Street Journal, citing \"people familiar with the matter,\" reported Major League Baseball is looking into San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano for alleged violations of MLB's gambling policy.\n\nAccording to the newspaper, the 24-year-old Marcano was accused of wagering on Pittsburgh Pirates games last season when he was on the team's injured list.\n\nIf that's the case, it could mean Marcano has broken baseball's golden rule of wagering and may be hit with a lifetime ban, just as the legendary Pete Rose was after an investigation found he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while with the team.\n\nThe Journal reported the discipline for Marcano has yet to be finalized, as talks between the MLB and the players' union are ongoing. However, the paper added that four other players face potential penalties for betting on baseball while still in the minors. There is no evidence at this point that the five fixed games, according to the WSJ report.\n\nBetting in baseball is a particularly touchy subject given the game's historical trouble with gambling, which includes Rose's ban. But, like other professional sports leagues, MLB has a black-and-white policy prohibiting players from betting on games involving their team. A printed copy of MLB's Rule 21 is even supposed to be posted in both English and Spanish in each team clubhouse.\n\nThe rule bars, players, umpires, and team and league officials from betting on baseball in general, with the penalty for doing so a one-year suspension. It also states that any MLB player who wagers on any game they're involved in will be banned permanently.\n\nBut MLB, again, like other leagues, is finding recently that having rules against gambling is not stopping players from violating those policies in the age of widespread legal sports betting. The \"Big Four\" leagues have all imposed discipline on players since the 2018 U.S. Supreme Court decision that paved the way for legal wagering to expand in the country.\n\nThat discipline is made all the more awkward given the business relationships leagues have formed with sportsbook operators since 2018, MLB included. So, as leagues are earning more revenue through the partnerships and the added advertising sports betting can help generate, they are also dealing with the headaches of players running afoul of gambling policies.\n\nMLB is still dealing with the fallout from another gambling-related controversy from earlier this year. The former interpreter for Los Angeles Dodgers star Shohei Ohtani agreed only last month to plead guilty to federal criminal charges in connection to debts owed to an illegal bookmaking operation.\n\nAlthough that incident involves illegal betting, gambling-related controversies have prompted some sports governing bodies to reconsider what they think bettors should be legally wagering on.\n\nMost notably, the NCAA has been lobbying state lawmakers to ban college player props over concerns about student-athlete harassment.\n\nThe NBA, meanwhile, is reportedly interested in tweaks to betting markets as well after former Toronto Raptor Jontay Porter was banned for gambling on league games, among other things.", "source": {"uri": "covers.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8160015021", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:11:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:11:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:11:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/sports/national/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says/article_cfe606a7-b2eb-5284-9933-60e9a4a5f14c.html", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, AP source says", "body": "By RONALD BLUM - AP Baseball Writer\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano is under investigation by Major League Baseball for allegedly betting on baseball and could be subject to a possible lifetime ban, according to a person familiar with the probe.\n\nMLB is looking into allegations Marcano bet on games involving the Pittsburgh Pirates while on the team's injured list last season, according to the person who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMarcano, 24, has not played since tearing his right ACL last July 24. He was claimed by the Padres off waivers on Nov. 2 and placed on the 10-day injured list March 19.\n\nMLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Buffalo Diocese plans to cut number of parishes by a third in latest restructuring Alan Pergament: Kate Welshofer has a new gig at the National Comedy Center Diocese cancels concert that includes gay chorus, cites values 'inconsistent with Catholic teaching' Bills observations: Damar Hamlin shines, secondary clings to WRs downfield 6-year-old girl dies after being hit by van in Town of Tonawanda Bills Mailbag: Why Tyler Bass is a cause for concern entering 2024 season At St. Margaret's, some congregants worry about its fate Western New York towns that host prisons wait to see if their facilities will close Erie County real estate transactions How the Sabres scouted, drafted QMJHL top defenseman Vsevelod Komarov La'el Collins healthy, eager to show Bills his top tackle form Explainer: Fabricators essential in producing local steel for Bills stadium project Mats Lindgren among trio of prospects Sabres opt to not sign before deadline Buffalo hires lawyer convicted of filing false documents with IRS to city job Ryan O'Halloran: New number, new position coach, new outlook for Bills cornerback Kaiir Elam\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. He has played in both the infield and outfield.\n\nAP Sports Writer Greg Beacham contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/mlb\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161514439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:03:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:03:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:01:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.inquirer.com/phillies/phillies-gambling-suspension-minor-leaguer-mlb-ban-20240604.html", "title": "MLB suspends Phillies minor leaguer Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez for one year for betting on baseball", "body": "MLB says Rodriguez placed 31 baseball bets when he was a minor leaguer with the White Sox, and some involved the major league team.\n\nPhillies minor league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez was suspended for one year for violating MLB's betting rules and policy, the league announced on Tuesday. In a statement, MLB said it conducted a thorough investigation of five major and minor league players, all of whom were disciplined to varying degrees.\n\nPer the release, betting data showed that Rodr\u00edguez placed 31 baseball bets on Sept. 30, 2021 and from June 5-30, 2022. At the time these bets were placed, he was on a minor league deal with the Chicago White Sox, and some of those 31 bets involved the White Sox major league team.\n\nMLB said Rodr\u00edguez bet a total of $759.09 on baseball, $724.09 of that on MLB. The league said the 23-year-old infielder was not involved in any of the games he bet on, adding that \"there is no evidence to suggest -- and Rodr\u00edguez denies -- that any outcomes in the baseball games on which he placed bets were compromised, influenced or manipulated in any way.\"\n\n\" READ MORE: Sielski: Angel Hernandez 'retired.' Good. Now bring on the robots and protect sports' integrity.\n\nThe Phillies acquired Rodr\u00edguez in April via trade from the White Sox for cash considerations. He has been playing for double-A Reading, and ranked No. 27 on the Phillies' top 30 prospect list.\n\nIn a statement, the Phillies said:\n\n\"The Phillies were disappointed to learn of the matter involving Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez. While we cannot comment on the details, we fully support MLB's sports betting policy and the need to adhere to all provisions of Rule 21. We will continue to educate all members of our organization regarding their obligations under the policy.\"\n\nAlso on Tuesday, San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned from baseball for life for betting on the sport. He became the first active player in a century banned for life because of gambling. MLB said he placed 387 baseball bets totaling more than $150,000 in October 2022 and from last July through November with a legal sportsbook.\n\nIn addition to Rodr\u00edguez, three other players received one-year suspensions for betting on baseball: pitchers Jay Groome of the San Diego organization, a native of Barnegat, N.J., the Oakland Athletics' Michael Kelly, and Arizona's Andrew Saalfrank.\n\nCommissioner Rob Manfred said the following in a statement released by MLB:\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans. The long-standing prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\n\n\"Since the Supreme Court decision opened the door to legalized sports betting, we have worked with licensed sports betting operators and other third parties to put ourselves in a better position from an integrity perspective through the transparency that a regulated sports betting system can provide. MLB will continue to invest heavily in integrity monitoring, educational programming and awareness initiatives with the goal of ensuring strict adherence to this fundamental rule of our game.\"", Pete Rose, baseball's active career hits leader, famously agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. {"uri": "8161424238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:58:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:58:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:57:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.covers.com/industry/tucupita-marcano-receives-lifetime-ban-for-betting-on-baseball-june-4-2024", "title": "Tucupita Marcano Banned for Life for Betting on Baseball", "body": "Major League pitcher Michael Kelly and minor leaguers Jay Groome, Jose Rodriguez, Andrew Saalfrank suspended one year for violating MLB's sports betting rules and policies.\n\nMLB has suspended five players for sports betting.\n\nThe league's Department of Investigations announced that San Diego Padres infielder Tucupita Marcano was permanently banned for placing nearly 400 wagers on baseball totaling $150,000.\n\nOakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly and three minor leaguers - Jay Groome (Padres), Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez (Philadelphia Phillies), and Andrew Saalfrank (Arizona Diamondbacks) - have been suspended one year for sports betting violations following a \"thorough review of available information in each matter, and significant cooperation from MLB's legal sportsbook partners,\" MLB said.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" said MLB commissioner Rob Manfred.\n\n\"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people. Since the Supreme Court decision opened the door to legalized sports betting, we have worked with licensed sports betting operators and other third parties to put ourselves in a better position from an integrity perspective through the transparency that a regulated sports betting system can provide. MLB will continue to invest heavily in integrity monitoring, educational programming and awareness initiatives with the goal of ensuring strict adherence to this fundamental rule of our game.\"\n\nThe five suspensions represent the latest sports betting controversy to hit MLB. Ippei Mizuhara, the former interpreter for Los Angeles Dodgers superstar Shohei Ohtani, is expected to plead guilty Tuesday to federal charges for allegedly stealing millions from Ohtani to pay off {"uri": "8161293264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:30:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:30:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:29:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.si.com/fannation/mlb/fastball/news/tucupita-marcano-banned-from-baseball-four-others-punished-for-gambling-jay-groome-jose-rodriguez-andrew-saalfrank-michael-kelly-01hzhsk9hgzg", "title": "Tucupita Marcano Banned From Baseball, Four Others Punished For Gambling", "body": "Five players received punishments on Tuesday under Major League Baseball's sports betting policy. Current San Diego Padres' infielder Tucupita Marcano was banned for life, as we had heard was possible on Monday.\n\nPer MLB.com's Mark Feinsand:\n\nMLB announced the following suspensions for unrelated violations of MLB's sports betting policy:\n\n*Padres INF/OF Tucupita Marcano: permanently ineligible\n\n*A's RHP Michael Kelly: 1 year\n\n*Padres LHP Jay Groome: 1 year\n\n*Phillies INF Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez: 1 year\n\n*D-backs LHP Andrew Saalfrank: 1 year\n\nMarcano reportedly gambled on baseball, including on his own team, while on the injured list last season. He was claimed off waivers by the Padres this offseason and hasn't played anywhere this season because he's been rehabbing a torn ACL.\n\nThe 24-year-old Marcano is a native of Venezuela who made his major league debut with San Diego during the 2021 season. He debuted with the Padres but got more time with Pittsburgh in both the 2022 and 2023 seasons. He's a .217 lifetime hitter through 447 plate appearances. He hit three homers during the 2023 season.\n\nAs for the other names on the list:\n\n-Kelly was the 48th overall pick in the 2011 draft. The 31-year-old is 43-50 in his minor league career.\n\n-Groome was a former top prospect of the Boston Red Sox and is currently in the Padres' organization. The 25-year-old is 19-34 in his minor league career and has yet to debut in the big leagues.\n\n-The 23-year-old Rodriguez debuted for the Chicago White Sox in 2023, playing in one game. He's hitting .265 this year at Double-A.\n\n-Saalfrank is 26 years old and made appearances for the Diamondbacks in both 2023 and 2024. {"uri": "8159998765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:55:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:55:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:54:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://chatnewstoday.ca/2024/06/03/padres-tucupita-marcano-under-investigation-by-mlb-for-gambling-on-baseball-ap-source-says/", "title": "Padres' Tucupita Marcano under investigation by MLB for gambling on baseball, AP source says", "body": "MLB's investigation was first reported Monday by The Wall Street Journal.\n\n\"We are aware of an active investigation by Major League Baseball regarding a matter that occurred when the player in question was a member of another organization and not affiliated with the San Diego Padres,\" the team said in a statement. \"We will not have any further comment until the investigative process has been completed.\"\n\nMarcano's agent, Michel Velasquez of Rimas Sports, did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. The Major League Baseball Players Association declined to comment.\n\nMajor League Rule 21, posted in every clubhouse, states betting on any baseball game in which a player, umpire, league official or team employee has no duty to perform results in a one-year suspension.\n\nBetting on a game in which the person has a duty to perform results in a lifetime ban.\n\nIn addition, betting on other sports with an illegal bookmaker is subject to discipline deemed appropriate by the baseball commissioner.\n\nCareer hits leader Pete Rose agreed to a lifetime ban in 1989 after an MLB investigation concluded he bet on Cincinnati Reds games while managing the team.\n\nThe last active MLB player suspended under the gambling provision appears to be New York Giants outfielder Jimmy O'Connell, banned for life along with coach Cozy Dolan in 1924 for offering a $500 bribe to Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Heinie Sand to throw a game that Sept. 27.\n\nMarcano made his major league debut on April 1, 2021, and has a .217 average with five homers, 34 RBIs and seven stolen bases in 149 games. {"uri": "8161563882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:41:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:41:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:39:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.si.com/mlb/mlb-officially-bans-tucupita-marcano-suspends-four-players-for-betting-on-baseball", "title": "MLB Officially Bans Tucupita Marcano, Suspends Four Players for Betting on Baseball", "body": "May 22, 2024; Kansas City, Missouri, USA; A general view of the baseball on rosin at the mound prior to a game between the Kansas City Royals and Detroit Tigers at Kauffman Stadium. / Denny Medley-USA TODAY Sports\n\nMajor League Baseball has banned a player for life and suspended four players for a year for betting on baseball, the league announced Tuesday.\n\nTucupita Marcano, an infielder and outfielder for the San Diego Padres, was placed on baseball's permanently ineligible list after an investigation implicated him in making approximately $150,000 worth of wagers on baseball.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" MLB commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century.\n\nMarcano is the seventh individual and second active player banned during Manfred's tenure, following New York Mets pitcher Jenrry Mej\u00eda in 2016 for performance-enhancing drug violations (Mej\u00eda was later reinstated).\n\nThe other four players who received yearlong suspensions were Padres minor league pitcher Jay Groome, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, Philadelphia Phillies minor league infielder Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez and Arizona Diamondbacks minor league pitcher Andrew Saalfrank.", Activate your Online Access Now\n\nOne other big leaguer, Oakland Athletics pitcher Michael Kelly, was declared ineligible for one year on Tuesday for betting on baseball while he was in the minor leagues. Additionally, minor leaguers Jay Groome of San Diego, Jose Rodriguez of Philadelphia and Andrew Saalfrank of Arizona were banned for one year for betting on major league games.\n\nThe league said it was tipped off about the betting activity by a legal sports betting operator. None of the players punished played in any games on which they wagered, and all players denied to MLB they had inside information relevant to their bets or the games they bet on -- testimonies that MLB says align with the data received from the sportsbook.\n\n\"The strict enforcement of Major League Baseball's rules and policies governing gambling conduct is a critical component of upholding our most important priority: protecting the integrity of our games for the fans,\" Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said in a statement. \"The longstanding prohibition against betting on Major League Baseball games by those in the sport has been a bedrock principle for over a century. We have been clear that the privilege of playing in baseball comes with a responsibility to refrain from engaging in certain types of behavior that are legal for other people.\"", "source": {"uri": Four other players affiliated with MLB teams -- Oakland's Michael Kelly, San Diego's Jay Groome, Philadelphia's Jose Rodriguez and Arizona's Andrew Saalfrank -- have each been declared ineligible for one year.\n\nMarcano is the most noteworthy player to be banned from MLB for life since Pete Rose in 1989, who was managing the Cincinnati Reds at the time after his playing career concluded.\n\nUnder Major League Rule 21, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has no duty to perform, shall be declared ineligible for one year.\" Whereas, \"Any player, umpire, or Club or League official or employee, who shall bet any sum whatsoever upon any baseball game in connection with which the bettor has a duty to perform, shall be declared permanently ineligible.\"\n\n{snip}\n\nRead more:
